		<username>Flagrant-Baronessa</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>This can impossibly appeal to an adult audience</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you voted 10 for this film, you'd better be 10 years old or else this is simply unforgivable.Pirates of the Caribbean is a truly excruciating experience. I hate this film on so many levels, covering so many aspects and ranging from crew to cast that it actually makes me physically ill to watch. So if I hate this film to the core, then what's the 2/10 for, you ask? The answer is; I think this film could be entertaining to kids and the odd pre-teen. It is, after all, a Disney production based on a popular Disney ride in a theme park and I think this explains its paper-thin plot of "saving the damsel in distress (Keira Knightley), killing the bad guy (Geoffrey Rush) and having an over-the-top comedic sidekick (Johnny Depp) whilst doing it".I don't know whose genius idea it was to cast Orlando Bloom as the romantic and heroic lead, but this choice helps him cement his position as the resident Hollywood lucky-guy, getting by without so much as a shred of talent, but inexplicably being offered big-budget project after the other. Furthermore, my theory is that Bloom's bad acting is contagious and affected the rest of the cast of Pirates of the Caribbean like a nasty case of the flu. Keira Knightley is a stunning woman but all she does here is pout with her pretty lips until she gets to deliver some cheeseball tough-chick line like "You like pain? *WHAM* Try wearing a corset." I'm no member of the Depp camp but I think he has pulled off some great performances in the past, but in Pirates, he is so over-the-top and corny that this can impossibly appeal to an adult audience.So aside from the cringe-worthy "corset" line by Keira Knightley, the dialogue-writing on the film really puzzles me. It's like it's camp but not intentionally. I believe this film truly thinks it's clever and amusing when it's only extremely embarrassing. Juvenile generic action sequences, long-drawn segments, contrived performances, dumb plot and overblown special effects make Pirates of the Caribbean an unwatchable adventure.2/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Pirates! What's not to love?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I guess I am a bit of a nut when it comes to pirates, but there simply aren't enough films that depict this brilliantly caricatured era.Pirates of the Carribbean adds to the mix a tad of supernatural elements and makes a very standard plot into a fun adventure by adding several memorable characters. The special-effects add to the feeling of the film, but at no point does the film become too big. There's no plot to conquer the world. 		<shortDescription>Great poster, lousy movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>To tell you the truth I can't remember much about the plot--and I just saw it last night! Something about a cursed pirate ship and its crew and how they all turn to skeletons when moonlight hits them and how they need some coins or something to release the curse...I was so bored during this film my mind kept wandering. Maybe I just don't like pirate films but I think there's more to it than that.This film has some major problems--it's way too long (half an hour could have been cut out easily); the story is (needlessly) convoluted and very badly done (I'm blaming the screenwriters and director, NOT the actors); despite all the explosions and fights the action scenes are surprisingly dull; there's loads of casual violence; leading lady Knightley is constantly being hit in the face and the admittedly great special effects just didn't grab me. There is a spectacular sword fight at the end with the men going in and out of moonlight and going from skeleton to man and back again--but it's too little too late. The direction is WAY off too--he seems unsure of how to frame scenes and it makes things very confusing.I can't fault the actors--Orlando Bloom (very handsome with beautiful black eyes) is very good in a badly written role. Keira Knightly's role is even worse--she's just "the girl" in the movie and no one could be good in it. Geoffrey Rush is OK as the pirate chief. Johnny Depp is the one reason to watch this movie. His performance is so off-beat and funny he keeps the film afloat. Just his mannerisms and facial expressions give an unexpected kick to lines.So...this handsome production sinks because of bad direction, ridiculous length and many many boring stretches. Unless you're a huge fan of pirate movies you can skip this one.</fullReview>

The acting is horrendous, Johnny Depp is like a washed-up rock-star, heavily drugged and very drunk, the entire time. Orlando Bloom is nothing but a simple rehash of the knight in shining armor, if only a bit more easily tolerated. Keira Knightley is just a damsel in distress, pure and simple, nothing else. Something I found ridiculous, was that every other character, even minor characters, mastered sword fighting. The humor is unbelievably childish, at several times it was on the level of the newer Simpsons episodes, which made me cringe more than I believed was possible. All of the CGI effects were very bland, most looked like they could easily have been made at the same mediocre quality several years ago. Why so many people claim this is a great film eludes me. If you ever even consider to sit down and watch this, make sure you keep your expectations very low. Very overrated. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone, as it is simply too long, too boring, too bland and too cringe-worthy to be the least bit enjoyable. 3/10</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Distraction for the brain dead</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If this is among the best from Hollywood, I don't think I'm going to another for a long time.I know I'm in the minority, but I just don't see the point of this movie. Its plot was totally predictable, filled with all the usual silly impossible heroics. The protagonists, by all rights, should have been killed many times over.The movie also had a rash of other implausibilities, e.g., no one on the protagonists' crew died despite sustained mortal combat against a superior foe, who by virtue of a curse, could not die. The ending was especially nonsensical: several times throughout the movie, Orlando Bloom had been condemned to death (of course, he implausibly escapes each time) after having saved the life of the beloved fiancée of the commander (and daughter of the governor). Then at the end, they simply lets him and his accomplice go?!?! Even the Johnny Depp character, which admittedly had some charm and craftiness, didn't make sense: why was he seemingly quasi-drunk all the time, slurring his syllables? And why all the eye-makeup? In the end, I wonder about all the money spent on this movie, and about a society in which a silly, pointless fantasy can be lauded as among the finest cultural outputs in years.</fullReview>

		<username>mrcinema-33590</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The Curse Of The Original</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As you can probably tell from the title, this film never gets old! "Pirates Of The Caribbean: The Curse Of The Black Pearl" is a swash-buckling pirate adventure/action film released in the summer of 2003. The entire crew working on this film were certain it would flop majorly in every sense of the word, as earlier attempts at kicking off a Pirate movie saga was met with little to no attention, and failed at gaining a trusty audience. But with the help of star Johnny Depp, as well as other notable actors, the movie grossed well beyond any other production in the box office at the time, amazing and surprising its creators. The movie is pure fun, from the way the characters are introduced for the first time to the action of the saga's original tale, scored beautifully by Hans Zimmer (One Of The Best Alongside John Williams). The music has that pirate feel to it, the awesome intensity of the action taking place and the confused but comical little tune that plays as Jack Sparrow stumbles around in the mystery. Johnny Depp gives a majorly entertaining and unique performance of Jack Sparrow, a dwindling hero with his own goals and aspirations. The character is immediately welcome alongside the likes of such action heroes as: Indiana Jones, Luke Skywalker, The Terminator and more..! The other characters receive the same amount of dedication, Will Turner (Orlando Bloom), Elizabeth Swan (Keira Knightly) alongside many more all have interesting and well written arcs. The movie also looks great, the visuals in some shots are stunning, though some of the CGI looks just a bit unfinished. As stated before, the original Pirates of the Caribbean film is pure fun and a great couple of hours to spend. It is... without a doubt, the best one out of the current four. SAVVY?</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Johnny Depp- Captain Jack Sparrow Orlando Bloom- Will Turner Keira Knightley- Elizabeth Swann Geoffrey Rush- Captain Hector Barbossa The plot of Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl is pirates on the black pearl needed to get the last piece of gold returned with the blood of the pirate who has it. The last piece of gold is in the hand of Elizabeth Swann who encountered it when her father rescued a boy named Will Turner. He had it around his neck and Elizabeth thought he was a pirate so she took it from him to save his life. Captain Barbossa and his pirates find the last piece of gold and kidnap Elizabeth to get it. With this going on Will is in love with her and needs to save her so he asks help from Captain Jack Sparrow, who wants the Black Pearl back that he once was a captain of. During the movie many encounters happened between the two pirate groups. One group being Captain Barbossa's and the other being Captain Jack Sparrow's. Captain Barbossa's pirates want to regain life back and not become skeletons in the moonlight while Captain Jack Sparrow's pirates are trying to save Elizabeth and get the Black Pearl back for Captain Jack Sparrow. The theme of this movie comes from a ride at the Disney theme park. It is a fantasy movie because it does not happen in real life. The theme of this movie is to catch the viewers' attention by making them think it is real life. Camera angles during this movie helps that part. The angles of the camera when the movie is shot makes the scenes when the fighting takes place more real life. It gets you close and up personal. Also the lighting during the movie sets the mood. Most of the scenes are darker with less lighting making it not scary but letting the viewer know that something is going to happen like the fighting or when the moon light is out and the pirates turn into skeletons. The theme of this movie to me a great. I liked this movie and will watch it more times to come. This movie kept it interesting throughout the whole time.</fullReview>

		<date>2005-04-03</date>
		<username>arsharp</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Use in classroom</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I teach English I in Dimmitt Texas and use this movie in the Media Focus portion of my curriculum. It contains excellent examples of many of the film elements on which I concentrate in this unit. I have been showing the VHS because I did not have the DVD. I recently purchased the DVD and found that the "making of the movie" selection will be of great benefit to my students during the Media Focus unit. For many of my students, movies are a luxury they seldom afford, so they enjoy watching in class. These students are very fascinated with the "how'd they do that" component of movies. My focus on media is that almost all media is trying to sell you something. Some of my students can relate scenes from various movies that contain "plugs" for various products. These students are pleasantly surprised to find none of these overt efforts to promote particular products in this movie. I seldom watch a movie a second time until it has been five or more years since the first time I saw it. I watch this movie in class every year and at least once during the summer each year. Each time I see the movie, I find something to inspire new interest. I love it.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2004-10-11</date>
		<username>CurtMan@LVCM.com</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Entertaining Swashbuckling Fun</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl" is just the kind of jovial, buccaneering blockbuster that demands a sequel in the future. It is worthy sea-faring entertainment indeed, featuring glorious and realistic set design, spooky and impeccable visual effects, some fine, indelible acting by Johnny Depp (in his most whimsical performance yet), and some classy, comical dialogue between the British sea captains and the vicious, blood-thirsty pirates. A film that provides basically everything you might expect in this kind of fun-filled adventure, albeit somewhat overstaying its merry welcome and deviating enormously from its Disneyland theme park ride inspiration, hardly ever does this amusing, entertaining extravaganza of a movie go wrong. From the gorgeous costume designs to the murky, gloomy, and shanky sets of the Caribbean, pirates' ships, and lands ahoy, to the eye-popping, deceiving visual effects (I was chilled to the bone at the transformation of the "pirates in the light" sequence), aside from being sheerly entertaining and festive, this is one amazing technical piece of cinema. Johnny Depp steals practically every scene he occupies, and Geoffrey Rush is excellent and sinister in his villainous turn. It's about as high-quality fun as one might demand in a summer blockbuster, and will have you singing "Yo ho, ho ho" for days and days to come. A "pirate's life" is plenty the life in "Pirates of the Caribbean", an worthy, intelligent sea-faring adventure guaranteed to leave you, at the very least, plenty satisfied. ***1/2 out of ****</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>A movie that everyone of all ages can enjoy</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Not once have I seen a movie with such glory as Pirates of the Caribbean: Curse of the Black Pearl. Not once have I seen a movie in which anyone of any age or gender or whatnot can enjoy. I didn't think that the movie was going to be too good, but I went to see it because my mom wanted to, and left with a huge smile. The element that the movie contained was that of superiority above movies. While it contains such bathroom humor and immaturity, it also contains a sense of seriousness. The fact that the crew decided to use a navy ship for the Black Pearl and decided to build the Interceptor shows the amount of effort (effort musn't be disregarded) put into Gore Venbrowski's film. The action packed sea battles and sword fights had the whole audience wowed. Speaking of the audience, I also noticed that there were old folks, little toddlers, teenagers, and middle aged people all around. Johnny Depp puts up a killer performance, as does Orlando Bloom. Many new actors were casted as well, and put on a shocking performance. Y'all really should see this movie! Nothing beats it! 10/10 on my scale.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>nocera01</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Not all pirates are cold hearted</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Yo Ho, Yo Ho, a pirates life for me! The film, The Pirates of the Caribbean has a theme that is evident. The Pirates of the Caribbean shows that the central insight is the fact that not all pirates are cold hearted. They can show compassion and camaraderie. It was under the brilliant direction of Gore Verbinski (The Ring, The Mexican) that this film's theme could be so easily seen. The Pirates of the Caribbean is a visually pleasing display of a true pirate adventure. Captain Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp, Edward Scissorhands) steals the show by revealing that not all pirates are cold hearted. The story begins with a gold medallion found on a boy which is taken from him to protect his identity from the British Navy that he is a pirate. The evil pirate Barbosa (Geoffrey Rush, House on Haunted Hill) and his crew are drawn to the medallion and will stop at nothing to get it back to break their curse. Johnny Depp's character has little concern about the medallion, but does want to get his ship, the Black Perl, back. Will Turner (Orlando Bloom, Lord of the Rings) teams up with Jack Sparrow to fight the pirates to regain the kidnapped governor's daughter (Keira Knightley, Love Actually) regain the Black Perl and defeat the evil pirates. The lighting in this film says a lot to describe the contrast of good and evil. When the camera is on Barbosa and his crew it is very low lighting to give the audience a sense of darkness. When the camera is on Jack Sparrow and his crew the lighting changes, it is bright and gives a feeling of camaraderie. This brings us back to the theme of the film, not all pirates are cold hearted.</fullReview>
	</review>

Supported by Orlando Bloom as a reluctant son of a pirate, the two embark upon a quest to rescue a lovely lady, and capture a ship who's crew is under an interesting curse. The action was very well executed, and the plot kept you going through the over two hour movie. A testament to it's character is that you really do not notice the time passing. Johnny Depp shows us again why he is an acting force to be reckoned with, choosing obscure and lucrative roles for our imaginations. This particular character is like none other than he has ever played. New viewers (or even returning viewers) should pay close attention to Depp's facial expressions, particularly in scenes where the focus is not on his character. 	<review>
		<date>2004-07-03</date>
		<username>djfatsam69</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>It's a comedy and a romance and I feel it's all the better for it.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In the mid-18th century, it can be difficult for a motley crew of pirates to make a name for themselves on the high seven seas. The Black Pearl is the exception. Boasting a star-studded crew, this whale of a ship has already slaughtered the US Box Office, and is set to do the same when she sails to European shores later this month. Featuring plenty of buckling swash, 'Pirates of the Caribbean: Curse of the Black Pearl' is quickly becoming this years must-sea action/ adventure blockbuster. Inspired by the infamous ride of the same name at Disneyworld, Producer Jerry Brockheimer has made sure no expense has been spared to reproduce a big screen replica that keeps true to the genre of a swashbuckling pirate adventure. Do not fear though! If you've been waiting for a decent pirate film for this decade, that spares you corny accents and puns, then this could just be the film for you!The film's plot is centered on the cursed, un-dead pirates of the mysterious ghost ship of legend ? the Black Pearl. She and her compatriots are on a quest. A quest to find all the Aztec gold medallions that cursed them. And it just so happens that a child Elizabeth Swann stumbles upon one around the young Will Turner's neck when he is rescued by Swann and her father, Governor Weatherby Swann (Jonathan Pryce). Unfortunately, the medallion, which Elizabeth took to hide Will's piracy, sends out a signal to the pirates when it falls into the sea years later ? a time when Elizabeth is set to marry Commodore Norrington (Jack Davenport); and a blacksmith Will Turner can only look on as his love is married (His love being Elizabeth not Norrington). Thus a hoard of gibbering, unkillable pirates; led by Captain Barbossa (Geoffrey Rush), follows to destroy the town of Port Royal where Swann is living, and retrieve their stolen item. Thus, with her having been kidnapped by the pirates, heart-broken gentlemen Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and Norrington set sail after the Black Pearl. Sounds good doesn't it?Yes, but it's not perfect. The plot is riddled with holes, so it doesn't all make total sense, but like the ride it is based on, the film moves on before you have time to think too hard about anything. However, don't go to this film wanting an ideal remix of an old genre; yes Verbinski and Brockheimer have breathed new life into the mould, but rather than getting a full on swashbuckler, it's a comedy and a romance, and I feel its all the better for it.The brunt of the goodness in this film is carried by Johnny Depp (Edward Scissorhands, Sleepy Hollow), who's comic portrayal of Jack Sparrow (Captain Jack Sparrow) is comparable to a drugged out rock star who clings to his half-fame like a life raft. It is a performance that could have been awful but he pitches it just perfectly and stops the film ever becoming anything less than fun. Zoom In Elizabeth Swann may have the looks and the rich ? posh background, but we quickly see her develop into an unusual heroine in this film. Unlike her contemporaries, such as Maid Marion in 'Robin Hood : Prince of Thieves', Miss. Swann plays a rather more pivotal role ? moreover, a more active role. Rather than playing a 'Damsel in Distress', a convention for women in this sort of genre, she's central to the story and gets involved with her own share of the action and the fighting, daring to attack the pirates and even Barbossa, and she saves hers and others lives a plenty. So although she may have the beauty, innocence, money, clothes, and the attraction to all the men around her like the traditional stereotype, she is not a girl to be messed with - feisty, smart, brave and witty. Definitely a 'Modern girl stuck in an eighteenth century world' (Keira Knightley on Elizabeth Swann).</fullReview>
	</review>

I didn't find the movie the least bit scary, but I wouldn't show it to a very young kid either as it would probably scare the pants off them. I liked "Pirates of the Carribean: Curse of the Black Pearl". It was cool, funny, thrilling, and had a lot of action. Although I am a big fan of Keira Knightley's and was disappointed at her acting in this movie. Sure, she was great in "The Hole" but in this movie I found her to be a bit over-the-top. I know Keira could've done better than that. On the other hand, Johnny Depp did great playing Captain Jack Sparrow. Keira's clothes weren't really appropriate for a PG-13 movie. But I thought this movie was a little bit too intense for a PG and for little kids under the age of 7 to watch. Some of the violence was just a tiny bit intense. In one scene they show Will running his hand up Elizabeth's chest, but I don't think it was meant in a sexual way, and some woman show cleavage and look like prostitutes. But I still recommend this movie. If you haven't seen it, you should!!Pirates of the Carribean :Curse of the Black Pearl has an interesting premise even if at first I was a little cautious about it. But we must look at it from the right point of view, meaning like a kid would. Who never wished to be to be a pirate? Even today I think about it.Johnny Depp is perfect for the role. He represents a feisty pirate captain. Orlando Bloom is also great as his tough, icy partner. The amazingly beautiful Keira Knightley however suffers from a huge lack of screen time. Her acting could also be better and we can clearly notice the girl has a huge ego. With her looks she can go far no doubt about it. But she has to be a little humble and be ready to learn. I'm not sure that is the case. With full knowledge of the power of her physical side she appears not the least interested and I would say even bored throughout the movie.The story is simple and without a touch of reality to it, just like it was supposed to be. The humor however could be more efficient. Some jokes, maybe too many, fall flat. The action could also have been improved. It's not even close to spectacular. The opening scene is very attractive but then all we get is some explosions and a few swashbuckling fights. There's also some violence, but nothing too extreme.Pirates of the Caribbean: Curse of the Black Pearl has some flaws. Its slow to build, some scenes fail miserably and sometimes its just too stupid.But since I'm not in its target audience. not anymore, I would recommend it because I still enjoyed it very much. It has a light, pirate atmosphere that works very well and provides an innocent fun. This was a very entertaining film for anyone of any age. It had cool action, and good special effects. Johnny Depp was good as Jack and was excellent at playing the beautiful Elizabeth Swann. When Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley), the daughter of Governor Swann (Jonathan Pryce) is kidnapped by a group of pirates led by Captain Barbossa (Geoffrey Rush) and taken aboard their ship, The Black Pearl, Will Turner (Orlando Bloom), the young man who loves Elizabeth despite the fact that she is promised to another, sets out to rescue her. But he can't do it alone, so he enlists the help of swashbuckling ship captain Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp). Together the two chase after The Black Pearl, but they soon discover that the captain and crew aren't your average pirates. Cursed to remain between the living and the dead, Barbossa and his men look like skeletons when basked in the moonlight. When it is revealed that the only thing that can break the curse is Elizabeth's blood, Jack and Will are faced with a race against time and a battle against the undead to save the Governor's daughter.Perfect Film to take the whole family to. This was also pretty funny. Very good action/family/comedy/pirate movie.Loved this movie! Saw a free sneak preview and would pay to see it again. Johnny Depp was crazy/wonderful as usual. Funny, creative, handsome, surprising - as he always is.Orlando Bloom was like a young Errol Flynn. He was a dream in Lord of the Rings and this proves that was no fluke. He can act, he's good to look at - has a sweet personality and the physicality to carry the role. The swordplay between Bloom and Depp was terrific!Geoffrey Rush pushed the envelope at being wonderfully hammy and the rest of the cast was simply great.Beautifully visual, a bit too long, but worth the ride. And I mean Ride!Really cool! 8.5/10I liked the action parts and the skeleton pirates. If you think of yourself in place of the actors,it helps you get a feeling of how the actor were.There is also romance at the end of the movie.I would recommend this movie.Went to see this on a rainy evening on vacation with my cousin. They loved it, and my parents and I enjoyed the experience too.Depp is an excellent lead - charming and likable, and the other cast members are well cast. Interesting story, good dialog, pretty decent special effects, great pace and length - what more could one ask for?AND IT'S NOT JUST ANOTHER FREAKING PIRATE MOVIE!!!!!!!!!!</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2004-03-01</date>
		<username>(omarhussaini@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Adventure on the high seas</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Peg-legs, swordplay, plank walking, ships, cannons and ancient curses. Now that's what a summer movie should be. We start off in the 1700s, give or take a hundred, in an island off - where else - the Caribbean. After 30 minutes of setup and character introduction, the island is attacked by the Black Pearl which takes Elizabeth Swann -the Governor's daughter- prisoner. But this be no random pirate attack. The pirates are victims of an Aztec curse that has left them in a state of undead and need Elizabeth's medallion to break it. The roguish Cap'n Jack Sparrow, former captain of the Black Pearl, sets off after them with Will Turner, his new sidekick. That's basically the movie. Now if you're coming into this expecting an intelligent drama about the dangers of sea life, well, forget it. Pirates is a movie whose sole purpose is to entertain, without insulting your intelligence, and entertain it does. It is one of those rare films that's good and fun, and much credit goes to Johnny Depp. One can only guess as to what compelled him to do away with the conventional Errol Flynn pirate and instead channel Keith Richards with a little PePe Le Pew. Depp is an actor who consistently rises above the script, regardless of the film's quality. The stumbling, slurred deliveries, facial expressions and goatee - things that would be out of place in another movie - only add to the performance because they fit in the context of the film. His performance is funny, eccentric, charismatic, and fully worthy of an Oscar nomination. It's time he got some recognition. Without him this would have been an average movie with a good performance from Geoffery Rush. As the mutinous first mate Barbosa, Rush also provides some humorous moments and has some good exchanges with Depp. Orlando Bloom is Will Turner, a blacksmith, who happens to be the reason for the curse. He holds his own as the movie pirate - looks, thinned mustache, ponytail - and Keira Knightley is even better as the damsel in distress. The production values - set design, costumes, cinematography -are first rate as are the special effects. The film also benefits from a rousing score courtesy of Klaus Badelt and Hans Zimmer. The movie could have spent more time in the editing room as it sometimes looses momentum. At two hours twenty minutes, it's about half hour too long. The direction is O.K. The battle scenes and sword fights could have been better choreographed. They come off flat and fail to provide any thrills. The only enjoyable one is the last one when Sparrow and Barbosa are moving in and out of the lunar beams. But these are just minor holes in an otherwise solid film. Pirates of the Caribbean is a fun swashbuckler with a good cast and should appeal to all, even if the wind occasionally goes out of its sails</fullReview>
	</review>

If anyone has gone through the Disney ride "Pirates of the Caribbean", you will find some great touches throughout the movie.Thoroughly entertaining and a must see!</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>I was resistant at first, but I am glad I yielded</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The only reason I even gave this movie a chance was because of the IMDB '8.0' rating it had at the time. That might be just a smudge too high but not by much. When I think of pirates I think of that which I have seen in the movies...PERIOD. Most pirate movies I've seen before were pretty much the same old flat characters or pirate musicals.I recommend this movie. It was extremely entertaining. It was fun. You will like it. What more do you want?Nearly every character was portrayed convincingly and interestingly. The acting did what it was supposed to do - give the viewer the idea of what the character is and does. A good script does this. This is a good script. There was a bit of 'Errol Flynn' hamminess to the action, but that's what made it fun. Lotsa plausible acrobatics. Fantastic but entirely plausible.The scenery and props were presented and the illusion was successful. This is good in a movie like this. Period pieces. I enjoyed every costume, wall, and shrub. The special effects are really special. Some introduce themselves in one of the most interesting ways I have ever seen. I wanted to sing 'Moonlight Becomes You' in my best MST3000 fashion.To top off those special effects you have a plot that is intriguing and a story line that pulls a few surprises. Thus, I will be watching this one again just to catch everything.Now, for me, the only flaw was that it seemed too long. The pacing is real good and the cinematography is superb but after a certain point my mind couldn't absorb anymore. It may have simply been because I was up the previous night til 3:00 AM fixing a 'bug' at work for a program that isn't even mine!....&gt;ahem&lt; scuse my rant...er..or maybe this movie did 'have too many notes'. A second viewing should confirm or dispel this. But I will most certainly enjoy the second viewing as I did the first.Good thrills. Lotsa excitement. Some definite laffs. Great special effects. Twists! Turns! Have some fun! Watch this movie.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2004-02-09</date>
		<username>Adrian Smith (trouserpress)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Johnny and the Pirates (Not very original I know)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In a summer full of blockbuster sequels like the Matrix , X2, Terminator 3, etc, it's great to see a new contender enter the ring. Okay, it's not entirely original as it's supposedly based on the Disneyland theme park ride of the same name, but I'm willing to forgive them in this case. This film is one of the funniest, most exciting and entertaining films I've seen in a long time. This won't surprise you if you're a fan of Mousehunt like me. In that film director Gore Verbinski proved that he had the great ability to balance slapstick comedy with dark subject matter. Given a larger canvas, exotic locations, a huge budget and Johnny Depp he has given us a movie that proves the potential he first showed.The plot follows the adventures of pirate Jack Sparrow as he attempts to track down his ship, The Black Pearl, and get his revenge on the crew that betrayed him. Meanwhile however the crew have fallen foul to an Aztec curse that has turned them into the walking dead, doomed to appear in their true form (frightening rotting corpses) when exposed to moonlight. This doesn't sound like the basis of a rollicking action comedy but believe me, it is. Johnny Depp based his pirate character on Ronnie Wood (of Rolling Stones fame), reasoning that pirates were the rock legends of their day, and results have to be seen to be believed. When you leave the cinema you will believe that Depp is the greatest actor of our generation, and if he doesn't receive an Oscar nomination for this I will lose all faith in the Academy. I wouldn't recommend this movie to younger children, as I think the scenes with the zombies could cause nightmares, but for everyone else - you must see this film!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>very entertaining</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I watched Pirates of the Caribbean after most of the rage about it had died down so that I could construct my own opinion about it. I had been very skeptical about the whole idea of a pirate movie because it was not a genre that I was attracted to at all. I believe that the movie was very well portrayed on screen by the actors, and the plot was very interesting. I constantly wondered what would happen next. It was not what I had expected from a pirate movie. I had expected the classic, search-for-buried-treasure-on-an-island story. This movie proved my skepticism wrong.I admit, the movie did seem too lengthy, but I couldn't imagine the movie any other way than it is. Part of my interest in the movie was the multiple themes it had. It was full of action, adventure, comedy, romance, and some drama. I think that this aspect of the film either attracted members of the audience, or turned them off in confusion. The movie must be watched more than once to fully grasp its whole feel. The audience must view it with an open mind for the movie to truly come to life.The fact that the movie had an array of themes also must have attracted a vast audience. The movie leaves no one wanting. The actors, especially, delivered spectacular performances, and the whole movie was made believable, and reeled me in. It is a very exciting and entertaining movie, and I believe most people would enjoy it.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2004-01-26</date>
		<username>(omarhussaini@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Adventure on the high seas</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Peg-legs, swordplay, plank walking, ships, cannons and ancient curses. Now that's what a summer movie should be. We start off in the 1700s, give or take a hundred, in an island off - where else - the Caribbean. After 30 minutes of setup and character introduction, the island is attacked by the Black Pearl and Elizabeth Swann, the Governor's daughter, is taken prisoner. But this is not a random pirate attack. The pirates are victims of an Aztec curse that has left them in a state of undead and need Elizabeth's medallion to break it. The roguish Cap'n Jack Sparrow, former captain of the Black Pearl, sets off after them with Will Turner, his new sidekick. That's basically the movie. Now if you're coming into this expecting an intelligent drama about the dangers of sea life, well, forget it. Go see Master and Commander instead. Pirates is a movie whose sole purpose is to entertain - without insulting your intelligence - and that's what it does. It is one of those rare films that's both good and fun, and much credit belongs to Johnny Depp. It is a mystery as to what compelled Depp to do away with the conventional Errol Flynn pirate and instead channel Keith Richards with a little PePe Le Pew. Depp is an actor who consistently rises above the script, regardless of the film's quality. The stumbling, slurred deliveries, facial expressions and goatee - things that would seem out of place in another movie - only add to the performance because they fit in the context of the film. His performance is funny, charismatic, eccentric, and fully worthy of an Oscar nomination. About time he gets some recognition. Without him this would have been a (marginally) bad film with a good performance from Geoffery Rush. As the mutinous first mate Barbosa, Rush also provides some humorous moments and has some good exchanges with Depp. Orlando Bloom is Will Turner, a blacksmith, who happens to be the reason for the curse. He holds his own as the movie pirate - handsome, thinned mustache, ponytail - and Keira Knightley is equally good as the damsel in distress. The production values - set design, costumes, cinematography - are first rate as are the special effects. The movie could have spent more time in the editing room as it sometimes looses momentum. At two hours twenty minutes, it's about half hour too long. The direction is decent but should have been better. The story is well told but drags whenever Depp's not onscreen. The battle scenes and sword fights could have been better choreographed. They come off flat and fail to provide any thrills. The only enjoyable one is the last one when Sparrow and Barbosa are moving in and out of the lunar beams. Pirates of the Caribbean is a fun swashbuckler with a good cast and should appeal to all, even if the wind occasionally goes out of its sails.</fullReview>
	</review>

My parents weren't very supportive of that b/c they didn't think it looked that good, but my mom eventually took me to see it and she loved as did I! Orlando was good in this movie but Johnny MADE the movie. Not only was it an absolutely brilliant performance by him, but he looks incredibly hot! Orlando looks good too. Geoffrey Rush did an amazing job playing Barbossa as did Keira playing Elizabeth. I would definitely give this movie two thumbs up. It's a great movie for the whole family to watch together. This is definitely one of the best movies I've ever seen!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2004-01-24</date>
		<username>Imnozy</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>HMS Pinafore meets Raiders of the Lost Ark</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This rollicking film version of Disney's most popular ride brings the viewer everything they expect ? sword fights, gun battles, debauchery, alley cats, the whole lot delivered with the tongue fixed very firmly in cheek. Central to the action is Johnny Depp's hilarious, camp portrayal of Captain Jack Straw, ably assisted by those two seasoned scene stealers Jeffrey Rush and Jonathan Pryce as Barbossa the cursed pirate and Governor Swann the father of the heroine Elizabeth. Keira Knightley gives a feisty performance as the girl who is promised to the stuffy commodore,but loves the humble blacksmith Orlando Bloom. Of the principals, only Bloom failed to make much impression, although much of that could be due to the fact that his character is fairly `straight' and all the others are so over the top.Depp's performance is so reminiscent of HMS Pinafore, that I kept expecting him to burst into song - `I am the Pirate King' ? and the non-stop hilarious action , thrills and special effects owe more to Raiders of the Lost Ark than to the pirate movies of the 40s. The plot is pretty thin, but why expect more of something of this genre ? the performances are flawless, the thrills and the laughs come one on top of the other ? this is a movie made to entertain not to make you think. A thoroughly enjoyable movie.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Let me just say that without Johnny Depp's performance this would only be a so-so adventure film by Gore Verbinsky (who did an amazing job with "The Ring"). After his overrated debut in the "Lord of the Rings" trilogy, he chose to change bow and arrow against swords. He's decidedly lovely but utterly deadpan, his lines come out badly (how did he ever manage to go through acting school?), and his performance as Will Turner is quite clumsy. One wonders what he will do in a part that requires no fight scenes...</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2004-01-09</date>
		<username>(poorlittlerichboy@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A brilliantly constructed, rip-roaring sea adventure!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>BEWARE: THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS FOR THIS FILM!THE GOOD:--The action sequences are fabulous and the movie is jam-packed with them. In particular the sword-fight between Johnny Depp and Orlando Bloom is very cool, as is the final big fight with all the CGI pirate skeletons facing off against the humans.--Gore Verbinski pulls some great performances out of his very talented cast. The stand out is, of course, the phenomenal Johnny Depp. His performance as Jack Sparrow is oozing with charisma and presence, Depp is just a joy to watch as usual. Geoffrey Rush is very convincing as the man who was rumoured to be so evil that he was "spit out of hell itself". Orlando Bloom is a charming, doe-eyed performer and given more to do than he was in the Lord of the Rings movies. Keira Knightley is babelicious to say the least and also a very good actress (seen also in "Bend it Like Beckham").--The CGI in this film is unforgettable, certainly some of the best work of 2003. The pirates were extremely convincing and looked awesome, I loved the way the movie darted from CGI to real and so on. The big action sequences were filmed with finesse and their effects were also great.--This is a film for virtually everybody. It is popular worldwide among all ages, and ended up for me being the biggest surprise of 2003 (be honest, who expected this film to be as great as it is?). Why is it that it was so popular? Because there is something for everybody here. You've got all the action and adventure on the high seas, a sweet, believable romance, lots of great physical comedy and some good suspense drama thrown in there for good measure. I loved how the film managed to mix all this in without ever losing sight of the plot and where the story is going.--This fun film is based on an adventure park ride, and I thought that director Verbinski and his team do a great job of giving the film the feeling of a ride come to life. A lot of the time I felt like I was in the movie as it was so energetic and involving - especially the scene where Keira Knightley is thrown from dead pirate to dead pirate in our first encounter with the not-so-human baddies.--I loved the score to the movie, it gave a very old-fashioned feeling to the piece and it fits well because "Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl" is an old-styles movie, a throwback to the great, classic swashbucklers of past ages.THE BAD:--The only place the movie cops out a bit is in the way it can be a bit Disney-ish. I hated the unfunny eye-losing pirate, and some of the other pirates were a bit too cliché and supposed to be comic relief when they were really just annoying background characters. I would've also appreciated a bit more gore and on-screen blood and killing, which is probably asking to breach the PG-13 rating, God forbid.RATING:9/10 - Terrific, rip-roaring old school action/adventure that never gets old at 143 minutes and leaves you begging for a sequel.IF YOU LIKED THIS MOVIE I RECOMMEND:Bend it Like Beckham (8/10) The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (9/10) The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (10/10) The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (10/10) Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (9/10)</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<username>GirlwonderReturns</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Thanks to Depp, better than expected</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I didn't see this film in the theater, mostly because the premise just didn't interest me much - a movie based on a theme-park ride?? You've gotta be kidding me. Even after many of my friends saw the film and told me it was worthwhile, my hesitation continued. Finally, just the other day, I was overruled at a friend's house and had no choice but to watch it or go home. And it was cold outside! Having now seen the film, I must first say: thank god for Johnny Depp. Because without his hilarious and utterly original performance as the slightly mad and infinitely colorful Captain Jack Sparrow, I probably would have hated this film. Moving like a man who has forgotten how to walk on land, with his unusual accent and flamboyant gesticulation, Captain Jack is a guy you just have to like. But every time the action moved away from him, I tended to lose interest. I don't mean to slam the rest of the cast - they were all solid. And the film's production values are also fine, with excellent special effects and cinematography. But with the exception of Depp's performance I didn't find anything truly remarkable about it, even considering its genre. The film simply belongs to him.Since POTC's release, fans have been suggesting that Depp receive an Oscar nomination as Best Actor. Although I've been a fan of his for years, I couldn't imagine it - not for this (again, a movie based on a theme-park ride??), anyway - but now I understand. The Disney Corporation should be thanking their lucky stars that the man accepted the role, because without Depp, POTC would be hardly worth remembering at all, and an actor who can carry a film in such a way is a brilliant actor indeed.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Stu Chandler (chanelit-1)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>High Seas adventures - terrifically Entertaining!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is one fun movie and well, the typically excellent Johnny Depp is absolutely pitch perfect as 'Jack Sparrow', playing him with just the right sense of 'tongue in cheek' and sincerity rolled into one.The premise is simple - there's a ship called 'The Black Pearl' which is rumoured to have a ghost crew, led by a captain 'so evil, hell spat him out'. Elizabeth Swann (a duly beautiful Keira Knightley) gets kidnapped by the crew and her childhood friend Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) sets out to save her, with the help of Jack Sparrow, the only pirate who knows how to get to the dreaded 'Black Pearl'.Cue endless adventures, swordfights, mirth, comic twists and the hunt for buried treasure and you have one of the most solidly entertaining blockbusters of many years. It's aimed at all ages, but with a subtle humour and knowing for the adults.Terrific fun - worth watching and far more entertaining than it perhaps deserves to be, you'd be a fool to miss this one.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Pirates of the Caribbean is one of the best films of 2003 and is the best film of the summer. It features all the perfect elements of a great film: romance, laughs, adventure, action, and walking skeletons. The pirate film genre has been sucsessfully brought back to life due to a great cast. Elizabeth Swan (Kiera Knightly) is the Govener's daughter in the Caribbean who found a cursed pirate medallion. When pirates, led by the relentless Captain Barbossa (Geoffery Rush), kidnap Elizabeth in order to break a deadly curse, Will Turner the blacksmith (Orlando Bloom) and the hillarious Captain Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) set out to rescue her. Throghout the dangers of the high seas, there are planty of laughs, thrills and chills. The pirates have a frightening secret that can only be cured from the blood of the child of Bootstrap Bill. Soon, everyone realizes whose blood must be spilt.Orlando, Geoffery, and Kiera make outstanding performances in this film but Johnny Depp is worth the video rental price alone. 	<review>
		<date>2003-12-05</date>
		<username>Kyrane</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Blockbuster of the Summer DVD of the Winter</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>MY PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN REVIEW THE MOVIE Movies about cursed pirates died out and flopped decades ago but this movie is brings new enthusiasm the pirate genre has been looking forward to. This is a great popcorn flick that has really put the Swash back into BucklingThis action/ adventure/comedy is loosely based on the ride at Disneyland. Although the similarities are somewhat few and far between this is probably a good thing as it escapes the Disney marketing attempt feel.The extremely well chosen cast could never be better with Johnny Depp brilliantly playing the light-hearted mostly-drunk pirate Jack Sparrow (sorry Captain Jack Sparrow). He provides most of the comedy in his one-liners, lucky escapes and defiant bragging. The romance is between the kidnapped Governors daughter Elizabeth Swann, (Kiera Knightly) and Will Turner (played wonderfully by man-of-the-moment Orlando Bloom) who comes to her rescue. The typical cursed pirate, Captain Barbossa of the titular 'Black Pearl' (played by Geoffrey Rush) is the all round bad guy shouting traditional pirate phrases. The CG (done by Industrial Light and Magic) is literally ground breaking with cursed pirates turning from skeletal to flesh as they battle in and out of moonlight. This gives both an eerie and astonishing effect.To round off there are action scenes galore with numerous sword fights and canon fire which are amazing and really keep the film up to speed.THE EXTRAS No DVD is complete nowadays without extras. With a full extra disc there is quite a lot to keep one amused for hours. There are three commentaries, which really depend on what you want to get out of a commentary the first is with Gore Verbinski (director) and Johnny Depp, which is surprisingly quite dull mainly thanking various people for hard work. If you are looking for trivia then the partial commentary with Jerry Bruckheimer (producer) or commentary with scriptwriters is for you, but the one I found the best is the commentary with actors Kiera Knightly and Jack Davenport (who plays Commodore Norrington) This commentary is also partial but is the funniest. The partial commentary is something I have never come across before but is quite an advantage, as you don't have to watch the whole film again and listen to people drone on about scenes that weren't really important to them. The downfall I felt to this DVD is the interactive menus which if you just want to get the film to play means time is lost waiting for menus to load. Back to positive and the second disc holds loads of good stuff. The first I checked out was the blooper real with the actors messing up, which you don't quite often get to see. The bad thing about this is that it was only 3mins. There are 19 deleted scenes, which I didn't really feel were very interesting so it just as well they stayed deleted. There are many different featurettes on this disc. The ones I'm liking the most is the Epic at Sea, Diary of a Pirate and Fly on the set which are all on the set interviewing actors etc. which prove very interesting and in depth. There is also `Walt Disney Wonderful World of Color' which shows a bit about the ride for all who haven't been on it. The last line is I think this is a wonderful movie and the DVD really compliments it well.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-12-04</date>

		<fullReview>This film is one of the best films I hve ever seen. I went to the pictures to see it five times and if I could watch it again right now, I'd be there! The camera angles and shots were perfect and caught every detail without making it boring.The script was wonderful and just packed with one liners that have now become well known sayings in many households already. The fight sequences were just right, they didn't drag on and you werent left sitting there saying "Oh the possibilities of that fight!"It was also such a well done period film that you didn't feel like it was a different period at all but like you were really there. I don't think I really have to comment on the acting because everyone regardless of having seen it or not knows how excellent everyone in the film was. Johnny Depp and Geoffrey Rush were both done up and acted so well that you would not have picked them from any other time, place, or film. Well Done 10/10</fullReview>

No I wouldn't give it a ten but just for the opening scene where Johnny Depp arrives in the docks it gets a 7. 	<review>
		<date>2003-10-26</date>
		<username>divaclv</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A fun ride</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A key moment in "Pirates of the Caribbean" comes with our first glimpse of Johnny Depp as Captian Jack Sparrow. He's standing proudly atop the mast of his vessel as it sails into Port Royal, hair rustling in the wind, the score thundering in full galleon-plowing-the-waves mode. Then a couple shots later, it's revealed that Jack's "ship" is a battered dingy so full of leaks that it makes the last several feet into port mostly submerged. The anticlimactic entrance sets the same tongue-in-cheek feel I remember from the Disney theme park ride which inspired the film. It's this sense of fun that saves the movie--if Gore Verbinski had approached the material in all seriousness (a la "Cutthroat Island"), "Pirates" would have been unendurable. As it is, we've got a nice popcorn movie on our hands, where the pleasures are occasionally guilty, but pleasures nonetheless.The "Black Pearl" of the subtitle is a pirate ship--Jack Sparrow's ship, or at least it was before his first mate Barbossa (Geoffrey Rush) led a mutiny and marooned him. But not long afterwards, the Black Pearl's crew runs afoul of some cursed Aztec gold, which dooms them to an undead existence (as Jack himself points out, the whole mutiny business kind of worked out for him in the long run). In a rather gruesome echo of "Swan Lake," the cursed pirates appear normal until exposed to moonlight, which reveals them as decayed cadavers. To break the curse, they need a certain medalion and a blood tribute, both of which end up involving the high-born Elizabeth (Kiera Knightley), and blacksmith Will Turner (Orlando Bloom), who worships her from afar.Along the way, there's as many chases, escapes, ship battles, swordfights, and general swashbuckling as you'd expect in this kind of film--perhaps even more. It's somewhat unfortunate that the best of these sequences should be the first, a duel between Jack and Will in a smithy. But there are some nice visuals during the climax, with the undead pirates darting in and out of shafts of moonlight.Ultimately, though, this movie belongs to Johnny Depp. He's made a career of playing characters who are slightly odd, but Jack Sparrow is perhaps the oddest of them all. Looking more than slightly seedy and moving as if he's perpetually falling off-balance, Jack has the manic gleam of someone who's very brilliant and/or very crazy. He doesn't just march to his own drummer, he's a rhythm all to himself. That Geoffrey Rush manages to match Depp for energy speaks a lot for his talent. These are two actors clearly enjoying themselves to the hilt, and their joy carries over to the audience. About all the rest of the cast can do is try to keep up with them. Bloom, who has the unenviable task of playing straight man to Depp, manages very well in the young lover role. Looking more rugged and less ethereal than he does in the "Lord of the Rings" movies, he establishes his candicacy as a bona-fide leading man. I also liked the work of Jack Davenport as the Royal Navy officer who's Jack's nemisis and Will's romantic rival. Such a character could easily have been your standard-issue unimaginative stiff, but Davenport fleshes out the part nicely.The greatest weakness of "Pirates" is the ending, which extends the resolution out far longer than feels necessary. But the trip there is a delightful one, delivering laughs and action in equal shares. Drink up, me harties.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-10-25</date>

Don't just watch this movie, buy it, memorize it, cuz i promise, it'll be worth it.</fullReview>

		<date>2003-10-19</date>
		<username>Douglas Young (the-movie-guy)</username>

		<shortDescription>Ship-A-Hoy My Matey</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Synopsis Spoiler! Ship-A-Hoy My Matey. As the title states, this is a movie about pirates who are under an ancient curse. Captain Barbossa (Geoffrey Rush) runs the Black Pearl with a crew of the undead. Because of the curse, the ship is doomed to sail the Caribbean Sea for eternity looking for the loss treasure. The curse will be removed if they are able to put all the gold coins back into the gold chest. Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) received one of these gold coins from his father as a child. However, Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley) took the coin from Will and has it in her possession. The pirates kidnap her and the swashbuckling action begins. Captain Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) helps in the rescue of Elizabeth and the return of his ship, the Black Pearl. 	<review>
		<date>2003-10-17</date>
		<username>Stephen West (steve70za@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Hoisting the Jolly Roger.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Most genres suffer the effects of booms and depressions associated with audience fickleness and the current trend. Only the Action, Thriller and Drama genres retain any sense of stability. Therefore the large ? scale investment in a movie which does not have the benefit of a boom period is a risky one. ?Pirates Of The Caribbean' is an attempt at regenerating the pirate movie with a movie so bold that it even has a sub ? title thus indicating the intent of future development of the concept. The pay ? off could be big or it could be a major loss. The achieved success is a consequence of the producers doing their homework. If it was a gamble, it was a confident one.The elements of its success are numerous, but the one's that got the attention were the story, the acting, the characters and the visual feast. No single element took centre stage and an excellent balance was struck which ensured that audience attention was not diverted by any one element being stronger or weaker at any point in the movie. Bruckenheimer's production style is well suited to a movie such as this and his experience in the production of several Hollywood blockbusters must have significantly decreased the risk factor.The story was a rich one that flowed gracefully introducing new characters at opportune times and providing sufficient obstacles for our heroes to overcome. This was crucial considering the movies length, although this time length is becoming more acceptable to audiences of today who are adapting as blockbusters are now being produced with involved stories which create greater character development. This is good for moviemakers who may sometimes find it difficult to condense stories to the allotted time limit.Suspension of disbelief was a subconscious one since the audience knew that it was watching a story which had the fantasy of a children's book. This is a natural component of stories about pirates since they conjure up an image of outlaws living outside the natural realm. Past stories captured our imagination as we were told of these barbaric beings that slipped out from under the shadows and plundered returning to their dark realm only to return to strike another hapless target. The great expanse of the ocean abound with uncharted territories and riches to plunder accentuated this quasi ? romantic image.The acting on show perfectly set aside each character as an individual who added to the story in their own way. Johnny Depp gave a style to his character that would have been amusing for the younger audience including enough expected character of a pirate so as to keep it in line with the story. As defined by him, pirates would have been something akin to rock stars in their time. This interpretation would have made it easy to be contrived which would have ruined the opportunity created for an original character. This was definitely not the case as the lines were sufficiently sublime and the acting was restrained enough so as to avoid a transparent performance. Let's not forget the assistance provided by the make ? up department in the form of eyeshadow. Which self ? respecting aspirant rock star would not have black eyeshadow? Our conventional image of a pirate was not portrayed here and this task was left to the character of Jeffrey Rush.This characters entrance was tantalisingly held back as the audience were given entertaining clues as to the character of Barbossa. Lines like ?he was spat out by hell' served to create an image of extreme depravity and insatiable greed. When we see him for the first time, this image is smoothly slipped into with restraint similar to that of Depp's. He is the archetypal pirate with which the audience will readily identify. We even have the characteristic ?Aaaaarrr'. As with the character of Depp, there is also originality although more in line with the producers' conception of the character rather than the acting adaptation of Rush. The parrot is traded in for a monkey. This is in tandem with his hyped up image of evil since the monkey looks more mischievous than a parrot. A pirate who is supposed to be the most evil of all must have the most mischievous companion of all.Who also gave a good performance and was consistent throughout. She did not fall into the trap of being too fragile and thus becoming a Scream Queen. Instead she developed into a heroine as she took the battle to ?The Black Pearl'. The originality evident in the characters of Depp and Rush was not adapted here which did not bring too much disappointment since she retained enough presence in their company. Although she looked like a clone from ?Titanic', she gave enough adventurous spirit and was therefore not as fragile as a ?rose'. Excuse the pun, it was hard to resist. The producers were right in casting someone who had a tried and tested look with the audience, but in doing so did not build on the originality as delivered by the leading men.The pirate movies that I have seen in the past all seem to visually fantastic. This one does much to continue this necessary trend. The world of the pirate is something otherworldly belonging only to our imaginations until some moviemakers give us their graphic depiction of this. The sets are at times spectacular in bringing this world to life. This movie does much to satisfy one of the requirements of the big screen which is to take our senses to another level. After all, the big screen is not ordinary ? it is grand. Why use a Mako as a prowler of the deep when you can use a Hammerhead.?Pirates Of The Caribbean' is an enjoyable movie, but it is not particularly memorable. This was probably not the ultimate aim of the producers. Audiences are looking for quick fix panaceas to their daily stress and in depth storylines do not provide this. The movie was aimed at profit ? taking in the short ? term. This means that the movie would have to be devoid of messages, but high on family amusement. This allows the producers to target the mass audience and thus make the movie more bankable. It is important to note that the story itself is not weak, it fact as previously mentioned it is a rich offering many avenues for entertainment. It does, however, fall short of the ideal for the stage that it graces. The grand stage requires a story of greater magnitude, which will entertain as well as teach for generations to come. Notwithstanding this fact, there are at present certain economic realities that the producers are paying attention to. Hopefully the future holds greater prospect for stories down the generations.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Holy Crap! A great movie based on a bad Disney ride!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As competing companies such as Dreamworks and Warner Bros. are laying down some new law on the animation frontier, what used to be the king daddy of all animation, Disney, is starting to be a mere shell of its former self, because of the focus on money and selling out rather than quality entertainment. The real success of Disney nowadays is from Pixar (which might defect from Disney) and some live action movies, especially "Pirates". This is a review on Pirates, so on with the review. Since about everybody saw the movie, I won't tell the story. I love the story (which goes beyond the damsel-in-distress quabble that may offset moviegoers at first). I love the effects (especially the skeletons). It blends my favorite genres (action and comedy) in a very good way. I like the acting. The only sort of problem is that the movie is a bit too overbudget, but that's no big deal, since that does not affect the movie in a negative way. I give this movie a 10 out of 10. 		<date>2003-10-05</date>
		<username>boxaridge4</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A Have-to-See Movie!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you like action movies,this one's a must-see! I'm a big fan of Orlando Bloom, and I went just to see his performance, but ended up liking Johnny Depp and Kiera Knightley's performances just as much. It's a perfect movie to see with the whole family, it's funny for the comedians in the family; action packed for your son; and if you have a daughter, she will love Elizabeth(Knightley) and may try to imatate her every action! Although, the skeletons mey be too scary for some younger one's, the movie's plot makes the skeletons more funny than scary. When I went to see it, I was expecting a more serious movie like Lord of the Rings, but it is far too histerical to even compare with Lord of the Rings. If you've been to the Disney attraction at Disney World, you will notice parts of the movie have parts of the ride in it, like the jailers trying to get the keys from the dog, or the one pirate sleeping with the pigs. You and your family will love this movie of the year.</fullReview>
	</review>

Orlando Bloom is always nice to look at whilst Geoffrey Rush is finally getting the exposure and the parts he deserves. The movement back and forth from human to skeleton isn't bad and the detail in the two ships is excellent. I found there not to be a moment where I checked my watch through the film other than when I had to go to the loo...there was a reason for the 90 minute feature...It's a bit of fun, and fun it is. 	<review>
		<date>2003-09-27</date>
		<username>fdextro</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Why do people fight an unkillable enemy? Answer:</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The one question that keeps popping up concerning this highly entertaining film is, why do people fight so valiantly against an unkillable enemy? Watch it again and you'll discover that no one believes in the curse. Those dutiful soldiers think they're just attacking a bunch of rag-tag flesh and blood pirates. When these scurvy knaves finally show themselves to be half-rotted skeletons, what are the soldiers to do? Lay down and die? Of course not, because if you were confronted with certain death, I'm sure you'd keep fighting in a manic (though futile) hope that somehow you'll live. In this case, that seemingly stupid effort works because of Depp's infiltration into the curse. Remember, Depp never bothered to lift a sword until he joined the curse, then battled away only to divert attention so the curse could be lifted, thus doing away with his mortal enemy in the most timely of fashion. So mateys, thar is your answer.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>It's late September and I finally submitted to pop-culture will and saw PotC:TCotBP in the theater today - and was very pleasantly entertained.I won't rehash everyone else's praises but the one thing I found most unique about the movie is that I found it very easy to root for everyone. 'Good' pirates, 'bad' pirates, british twits, 'chaotic' characters -- other reviewers complained that the movie tried to hard to make everyone funny, but I found it great that this was not a pure black-and-white good-and-evil movie. I *wanted* the black pearl pirates to get their curse removed, while also wanting Johnny Depp to get his fortune, while also wanting Orlando Bloom to get the girl, while also wanting.... well, you get the idea. In short, the way the story allowed viewers to root for everyone simultaneously was very refreshing.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>the best film ever</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This definately is one of the best films i have ever seen, and it has been the most popular film by far with many many people each week at the cinema i work at.the film has a unique and engrossing story line, incorporating many myths and themes that were around at the time of the pirates. the story centres around the initial finding of a piece of aztec gold, one of a large number of pieces which make a set. it may sound basic, but there's more to it, as the treasure is cursed, so anyone who takes even one piece of the gold becomes cursed. this is where the story kicks in, as a group of pirates have spent years trying to find all the pieces to lift the curse bestowed upon them. there is so much to summise from the fantastic plot that i won't waste time, and simply say just go and see the film. it's worth it, and besides, i'm not one to give too much away. but my pitiful summary does not do justice to the spot on story.the soundtrack to the film is by far the best music score i've heard in a film for a long long time, (with the exception of Moulin Rouge of course). it's lively, yet superbly classical.it has been fantastic being a projectionist for this film (among others) and I have seen the people coming out of the film just buzzing with excitment, all talking about how amazing it is. 	<review>
		<date>2003-09-14</date>
		<username>MaxKing</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A good old-fashioned, new-age swashbuckler picture!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Ah, now THIS is what I would call a nostalgic glimpse back into the films of Errol Flynn! From the very beginning, this movie sets itself up as the ideal old-school romantic adventure movie! I haven't seen a movie like this since the sixties, and I must say, it has been far too long! I had to sit back and just suck it all in, like a fresh breath of salty sea air, the first time I watched it. A delight! That's what it was: Simply a Delight! Alright, enough with the general singing of praise, hm? Specifically, the movie has all the elements of a movie that make it as great as a classic: Action, Character, Humor, and a Plot that's twisted into a pretzel! In the way of the action, what can I say? There's something irresistibly classic about a swordfight! And the fights were handled expertly in this movie! The stunts, too, were exhilerating to behold (Especially considering how little was done with CGIs, you know!). Moving on, the characters were all wonderfully charismatic in their own way! I think everybody's favorite would be Captain Jack Sparrow, the infamous, legendary pirate, portrayed by Johnny Depp! HE makes the movie purely enjoyable, because he is the amalgamation of the main hero and the comic relief! Also, his humor isn't so...blandly profane, as is usually the sad case this day and age. No, he uses the wonderful art of subtlety and sarcasm in all his dialogue, which makes his character all the more charismatic! The other characters include Will Turner, played by Orlando Bloom. His character is an appreciable variation on the ever-winning archetype of the young romantic hero. His character is even more interesting when you see to what level his swordsmanship is developed, having trained himself in the art while his occupation requires him to forge the blades. He's the amalgamation of the naive romantic hero and the skilled weapons-master, as offbeat a fusion as Sparrow's. Next, there is the leading lady, Elizabeth Swan, Keira Knightley, whose character is, situationally, the damsel in distress. But she is by no means the damsel who awaits rescue, fighting for herself! She is the problem solver, who conquers her challenges with ingenius solutions. And finally, we have the villain: Captain Barbossa, Geoffrey Rush. His character is the delicious combination of the sinister villain, and the everyday human being! Even as evil, vile, and diabolical as he is, there is something wonderfully REAL about his performance! He has a sense of humor, a sense of vulnerability in certain areas, and even a spirit of personal charisma, despite his grotesque persona and lack of morals. These characters also have intriguing relationships between themselves that make them even more enjoyable together! Turner is in love with Swan, and both struggle with that and the difference in their classes; Jack Sparrow is a pirate and a good man, a paradox that Turner and Swan have to come to grips with; Jack Sparrow and Barbossa have a long-lived enmity; Jack Sparrow and Turner become friends (rather analogous to Han Solo and Luke Skywalker); and Swan and Barbossa have a unique relationship as they are both as high class as the other, despite their affiliations, which makes for delightfully elegant dialogue between enemies! The characters also have their individual secrets...But it would be unfair to spoil the movie for those who have yet to sample it themselves. As delightful as it would be to describe myself, this is one of those movies that, like a fine Itallian dish, must be sampled personally! Now then, the humor! Oh, the humor! Everywhere you turn, there is a small joke thrown in! This is the defining twist that saves the movie from drowning in its own seriousness. It is necessary to make the movie fun (especially considering the macabre nature of the essential story by itself). Captain Jack Sparrow offers the most abundant source of laughter, with his Groucho-esque sarcastic response to anything spoken in his general direction! Also, his very character is as much a joke as a hero! Alongside him are two pirates, and two naval soldiers, who serve as a pair of "Abbot and Costello" comic relief teams. They are the fall down men, who are there for the sole sake of being taunted and ridiculed. A funny movie needs characters like them, for after all, what good is a joke without a butt? Finally, whenever Jack and Barbossa are paired together, it is the perfect Straight-Man vs Slick-Wit routine that never disappoints! Those two have a wonderful chemistry, and you can't help but love them together! Finally, the plot! An elaborately twisted, wonderfully convoluted, and sheerly wonderful piece of writing that is! I can't describe it, to be sure. That would be spoiling it, and I have no intention of that, let me assure you. That would be a crime! Suffice it to say that all the characters are believeably arranged into a spider-web of connections that all tie them to a small piece of Aztec Gold and a pirate ship! The web spirals in twisted loops, but streams unerringly towards an exciting conclusion at the center! What makes it even more complex is that there is as much story that is revealed as history as there is on the screen in real time! It is as twisted and convoluted piece of literature as I have ever seen! I could not find anything to complain about in this movie! Everything was wonderful about it! If you haven't seen this one, I assure you, you are missing a delightful experience that will remind you why you go to the movies at all! Rarely does a movie of this high quality come around, and even more rarely does it capture one's interest for two and a half hours! But this one met and beat all my expectations of a modern movie! This was the easily the most enjoyable film I have seen in a long, long time!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Yohoho... this is the movie for me</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As a whole, Pirates is a lot of fun... a cross between The Princess Bride and The Mummy. Johnny Depp is very, very funny... very campy... but the sexual appeal is rather lost on me. He certainly had the best lines and played them for what they were worth. That final scene with Orlando Bloom and Keira Knightley before he takes another plunge off the fort is utterly hilarious. Geoffrey Rush is amazing... quite the chameleon... enjoyed his snarly Barbosa. Orlando Bloom looks much better as a pirate than a blonde elf. I just took it for what it is... an adrenalin rush.</fullReview>

		<username>AllMT3</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Do you like PIRATE movies?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>You know the drill: Cursed ship, only one can break the curse, his girlfriend gets kidnapped by the undead, has to team up with a pirate to save her, blah blah blah.My two cents worth: I guess the first question on whether or not you should see this movie is; How do you feel about pirate movies? If you're not sure, try this: stand in front of the movie poster. If your reaction is anything other than, "Pirates of the Caribbean! Cool!" then nothing will salvage this movie experience for you. It doesn't matter how much you like Johnny Depp.For those of us who like pirate movies, this is a dream come true. We've got curses! Treasure! Pirates who have been out on that island too long! Funny one liners! Large complex sword fights in ridiculous places! Stuffy British naval officers! (And a plot with more holes than a latticework gazebo, but WHO CARES! It's a PIRATE MOVIE!)Recommendations: If you like this movie, I highly recommend Princess Bride (if you haven't seen it already). The original version (1950's)of Treasure Island is also good, and 20,000 leagues under the sea (it's better than you remember! I promise!) If you're a pirate movie hater (or just a movie on ship lover) any of the versions of Mutiny on the Bounty will do, also recommend the book "True Confessions of Charlotte Doyle" (it's a Newberry award winning 'kids' book, but adults will enjoy it too).</fullReview>
	</review>
