		<fullReview>this movie is a must see for movie aficionados and for any film student who wants a very well-made, yet also very entertaining movie with artistic value based on a screenplay that is also an excellent study tool. the action scenes are well-choreographed and well-paced, all scenes move the story forward. and all the characters are three dimensional. all have flaws and things they wished they could hide. well, i'm not sure if sparrow had something he wanted to hide, but either way everything in the story telling aspect is well fleshed out.and as for the VFX, the use of CG by ILM is gladly well used. and well executed. thanks to the famous john knoll, the same man responsible for creating the fx in such classic ILM films as T2, and even the new though not so engaging star wars prequels. the acting is superb. and as for the direction? gore verbinsky is a true artist. might i say he also helmed a very impresssive horror film, it's title THE RING has become a household name amongst some of the the more recent films of it's genre. though muddled with plotholes that film is also well worth a look. PIRATES is even better. i might just watch it again in the cinema. or purhcase the DVD. 10 out of 10. and be sure not to leave teh theater 'til after you see a little surprise after the end credits. i ended up leaving the cinema mouthing jack sparrow's words. 		<date>2003-08-22</date>
		<username>prestoni</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Rotten Ripe</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Getting lost in the sumptuousness of it all was easy to do watching the old masted schooners and the fierce hearties that sail them ballet across the screen. "Pirates of the Caribbean" is this summer's guilty pleasure for this old movie buff. Disney Films are still good at decorating legends and fairy tales that delight a child's imagination. Even the child that still remains in a codger brought up on Bambi and Snow White and The Alamo (Davey Crocket version), the Spanish Main etc. etc.These new theaters with stadium seating are an answered prayer for old movie lovers. (I sure do like to see old movies in them.) You can actually see the entire screen from almost every seat, and it is huge, and the sound! My god, it comes from all over the place!! And if Orlando Bloom is not quite Errol Flynn, he makes up for it in earnestness and intensity. A standout in Lord of the Rings, this young Brit has matinee idol written all over him. (Do they still call them that?)So much had been written about Johnny Depp's performance as Captain Jack Sparrow. But I was not really prepared for the campy swagger, one critic said he sashayed, and by gosh, he did!! But remember his Bon Bon in that Cuban writers story. What ghoulish androgyny and eye-liner! An Ancient Mariner cum Flying Dutchmen in Disney-color, yet. I could not stop laughing. And the special effects and warty skeleton mates. Straining every digital trick yet available. It was a ghastly crew! And the real Dutchman in this patchwork fable, Captain Barbossa, is played by Geoffrey Rush, chewing the scenery and spitting out Elgin Marbles. Also the beautiful young (18?) Keira Knightley held her own among the talent heavy males, to be saved from a boring marriage, willing for Senta-like self-sacrifice.Needless to say, I loved it.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Alexandre Hotte (alien_Al77@hotmail.com)</username>

		<shortDescription>A Pirate's life for me</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The Pirates of the Caribbean is loosely based on an attraction rideat Walt Disney's World, of the same title, yet Ted Elliot and TerryRossio have written a suberb-pirate movie. Directed by GoreVerbinski whom we all know directed Mouse Hunt, The Mexican and TheRing, its a no wonder this movie is so entertaining in almost everyaspect a movie should have. Begining with Acting, Obviously, Johnny Depp stole the screen here. Every frame of celluloid he's on, you know its good. The loveableJack...ahem 'Captain' Jack Sparrow, is the perfect pirate, anypirate movie should have. Accompanied by Mr. Will Turner (played byOrlando Bloom aka Legolas) he must rescue the beautiful damselle indistress (Keira Knightley). Seems fair enough? But wait...there'smore! Our damselle is held captive on board the black pearl,operated by Capt. Barbossa (played by Geoffrey Rush).Well I won't tell everything about it, you'll just have to wait forthe DVD release...or go see it in the theatre. (Obviously, thetheatre being the better choice.)So go see it now, or as soon as possibe. Cause this is one goodmovie you wouldn't wanna miss. Bring a mate or two along if youshould, wouldn't want that curse taking you away.</fullReview>

		<username>organic_muffin</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Wonderful movie! Johnny Depp steals the whole show!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I can tell you this much: I haven't seen a movie so supremely entertaining since... well, since ever! I've seen it six times already, and am planning to see it again soon. The plot was complete (better than a themepark ride-based movie has a right to be), the sword-play was good, and the acting was just phenomenal. Although Orlando Bloom may be eye candy, I hate to admit this, but, he can't act. Keira Knightley plays the damsel-in-distress (although she does a better job of it than most other actresses would). But Johnny Depp completely steals the show! I didn't expect much when I first went to see it, but when he came on screen, I just couldn't take my eyes off him. Not only is Johnny Depp completely hot and very sexy, but he is just hilarious! When I first saw the movie, tears were coming out of my eyes because I was laughing so hard! He makes all the other characters fade away because he has such presence in every scene. Not to mention the accent. I can't believe some people have the nerve to say it was too long, because when I saw it, the time just slipped away and I couldn't believe that it was 2 hours and 23 minutes long! Kudos to the moviemakers for doing an excellent job on making the movie move along at a fast clip.The ONE bad thing about the movie is that it will be a horrible wait for the DVD. But when it comes out, I swear, I will be the first in line to buy it where I live. I give this movie a 10/10. It was simply brilliant. If you haven't seen it, RUN to the nearest theater right now and go see it!</fullReview>

		<username>quinlanjkkb</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A complete summer vacation rolled up into a 2 hour movie - What an adventure!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Captain Jack Sparrow (Depp) is absolutely entertaining, totally charming, but annoying at the same time. You never know where he stands or whose side he is on at any given moment. A true character! Will Turner is handsome and sweet, and totally love-struck with Elizabeth. The beautiful couple seem wimpy at first, but soon prove they are tough as nails when the chips are down. Her father and fiance are perfect! Captain Barbosa rocks! Aye matey, an excellent adaptation. I love the action sequences, especially the fencing in the blacksmith's shop. The fight scene on the ship was way cool! The two strange pirate partners are hilarious! Between the one's wooden eye escapades and the two of them dressed up as women, their antics added a bit of humor to the fight scenes and made the grossness of the fact that they were absolutely filthy more bearable. Terrific cinematography and special effects - even the music and sound effects wrapped you up in the time of pirates, heroes, and adventure! I will buy the movie and the soundtrack. Everyone had a ball as we were swept away to a different land and time - what a vacation!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-08-17</date>
		<username>rogerdarlington</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Made me a jolly Roger</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Who would have thought that the pirate genre could be made to successfully walk the gangplank again? And who who would have imagined that producer Jerry Bruckheimer - the guy behind a succession of violent action movies like "The Rock" - would be the man to do it? But here we have family entertainment at its best - non-stop action, lots of humour, effective special effects and great locations (St Vincent). What really makes the movie though is the clever casting.Johnny Depp gives a marvellously camp performance as Captain Jack Sparrow, the most charming rogue ever to stride the decks. Geoffrey Rush, as his rival to command the "Black Pearl", is even madder here than in "Shine". British viewers of the television series "The Office" will find Mackenzie Crook giving an eye-catching performance. Orlando Bloom, after his heroics in "Lord Of The Rings", gives us some more dash and bravery. While young and sweet Keira Knightley, following her freshness in "Bend It Like Beckham", obtains the big break that is likely to secure her a successful career.All this made me a very jolly Roger. </fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>It's been said already but...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>... this really is the best action adventure film since "Raiders of the Lost Ark".Those were my words as I walked dazzled from the cinema last night, after 143 minutes had fairly flown by. This film has it all:* Eye candy for the boys (Keira Knightley), and the girls (Bloom, Depp, and Davenport).* Smart and snappy writing - very British humour, performed by well-known British character actors (and Johnny Depp, of course).* Direction and cinematography of the highest order. Even the late Sir David Lean would be in love with some of the compositions and camera moves.* Exceptional effects work. "The Hulk" was meant to be ILM's showcase this summer - but the work here simply blows the "Hairy Shrek" away.And as I've already mentioned, it sustains interest for nearly two and a half hours. The action sequences in the final act don't drag at all, by virtue of cross cutting between a number of interlinking story strands.I can't understand why anyone would say it went on too long, because it was such a phenomenal trip.In closing. I'm an enormous Spielberg fan - but I'd love to see Verbinski helm Indy IV....</fullReview>

		<username>clareangelus</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>arrrrr it be full o' piratey goodness</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Pirates of the Caribbean is by far one of the most entertaining films I have seen in a very long time. After the betrayal of Matrix Reloaded I was not prepared to enjoy this film quite as much as I actually did. Perhaps because it was not what I expected.It is not actually a comedy and despite the subject matter it ironically avoids descending into absurdity (unlike the last 3 James Bond films) to get big laughs. It does however have some golden moments, the dialogue is sharp, the story is coherent and believable.What is it then? It is a hard core action adventure and the strangest thing about it is how believable it actually is. I think this is because it offers something more than just great special effects and swash buckling sword fights (both of which give Gladiator and Lord of the Rings a run for their money).The characters have very human and real motivations: love, greed, honour, the desire to be free. All those visceral and primitive emotions that every human heart has experienced at some time lend that essential 3rd dimension to an otherwise conventional tale of high seas adventure, cursed treasure, and, of course, Pirates. There aren't any real surprises but at least you know what is going on.Johnny Depp is just magical as Captain Jack Sparrow but his camp Keith Richards swagger has excellent competition in Geoffrey Rush's villainous Barbosa. Again there was the potential for things to end up being cartoonish but the performances created authentic and interesting characters. Orlando Bloom's love lorn William Turner is just lovely on so many levels. Most of the fun comes from seeing how difficult it actually is to buckle a swash. What ever that is.It makes a change for the Characters and Writing to make the film instead of the effects.It is difficult to find something bad to say to about the film but since no film can be perfect I would have to say the least believable thing was the 'love interest'. But it is perhaps the habit that Hollywood has of putting 21st century females into period films that made her a bit too butch for a well born lady of the time. The fact that she could actually swim is even suspicious.Maybe it was just the air conditioned comfort that made it so good (it was 100 degrees outside at the time) but I am going to give Pirates of the Caribbean *3 pairs of pants.1. it was almost 3 hours long. In spite of its Piratey goodness no film has any excuse to last 160 minutes.2. I did not go to this film to see anything involving a woman. One could have easily done with out the wench in my opinion. The story would have been a bit different but no less interesting and probably much shorter.3. they didn't have my favourite candies at the pick and mix.4. the last 10 minutes or so did get a bit silly. I wont tell you what that is all about but I am sure you will agree a better ending could have been provided.5. For some reason it is affiliated with Disney.Ok I know that is five pairs of pants and I only gave it three but it was about PIRATES and let's face it, that Orlando Bloom is one exemplary piece of buccaneer booty. Huzzah!*please note that the clareangelus Pants scale is all about how bad a film ISN'T. The fewer Pants you get the better it is!</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2003-08-11</date>
		<username>Zeorymer</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Got Me Out of The Couch.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have to admit that I didn't have high hopes for Pirates of the Caribbean. Orlando Bloom speaks in a flat monotone voice, I had no idea of who Keira Knightly was, and I hadn't heard a peep out of Johnny Depp or Geoffrey Rush for ages. Besides, wasn't I too old for Disney movies anyway? After the poor special effects job I saw on Ang Lee's `The Hulk', I was wondering how the people at Disney could pull off pirate skeletons. What I expected and what I got were two very different things. Cursed undead pirates led by Captain Barbossa (Rush) kidnap the aristocratic Elizabeth Swann (Knightly) in hopes of removing the curse that turns them into walking skeletons by full moonlight. Her long-time admirer Will Turner (Bloom) sets out to rescue her with the help of wanted pirate Jack Sparrow (Depp). It's a conventional plot with conventional characters, and if I said any more, I'd ruin the whole story. Everybody played his or her roles very stereotypically. The person who single-handedly saved the show was Depp. Of course it looks like he's getting electric shocks to his face, and with all that makeup he might be an exotic dancer in the off-season, but Depp really got involved with his character, and it shows. He's always there to provide some hilarity to an otherwise dry movie. His dueling scenes with Bloom and Rush are easily among the best fighting sequences in the movie. (The rest of the fight scenes were pretty bad) Depp even had a handful of his teeth replaced by gold ones just to look the part. He had to take some out, or risk overacting. Although he'd reportedly like to be in a movie that doesn't involve swords, Bloom is certainly good with them. It's a long jump from a blonde archer elf to a swashbuckling blacksmith-turned-pirate, but he excels at it. All the sword handling he used as Legolas certainly hasn't gone to waste. However, the big fluffy hat with a feather in it that he used wore in the last few scenes looked terrible on him. Disney took a big risk on this movie. This is the first movie made by Disney to get a rating higher than PG. By getting a PG-13 rating, they risked alienating the moviegoers who thought that this movie would be more kid-friendly. The title was even changed from `Pirates of the Caribbean' to `Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl' in hopes that there could be a sequel. This is also the first live-action movie made by Disney in a long time. It's obvious that Disney poured a lot of money into this project, and Disney and viewers certainly got what they paid for. But this movie does have its downsides. Bloom and Knightly couldn't make a less convincing couple if they had been in separate movies. The movie did stretch on just a little bit too long, and it's hard to create life-and-death situations with pirates who just can't die. Too much of the pirates' conduct is governed by a set of rules, which are more like guidelines anyway, as is pointed out several times in the movie. Captain Sparrow spends too much time in jail, and past events are hinted at too much. Despite the length of the movie and all the rest of its shortcomings, Pirates of the Caribbean has revived a genre I thought was long dead and buried. A genre I thought belonged only to yesteryear. That's all I have to say about that.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<shortDescription>This is what Hollywood Blockbusters are all about</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>SPOILERS INCLUDEDThis film is brilliant! I'm an enourmous fan of films which encouraged you to think and consider parts of life. Truth be told though, my favourite character in this entire film is the character played by Mackenzie Crook (Gareth in "The Office"). Crook's evil pirate is excellent, casted perfectly &amp; at times hilarious. It is unfair however to claim he is the only one to provide humour. Every single person in this film provides excellent comedy.As well as excellent acting &amp; special effects in this film, there are many other possitive things. The music is as you'd expect by now, beautiful, the way the film flows is worthy of mention as is the strange feeling at times that you are actually watching a film which was filmed at Disney Land, and for once when watching this film, it finally feels like Hollywood has learnt it's lessons and returned partly to the types of film for which people like Errol Flynn were renowned.Pirates Of The Carribean is a stunning film which I recommend everyone watches. Watch once at the cinema (twice if you feel like it, but personally the only flaw with this film is the daft certificate and it's strange appeal to noisey little brats), and then over and over again at home with a beer or two. Enjoy!</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Depp's performance is a must see.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The plot of POTC has been outlined in some of the other comments so I won't rehash that. The film itself does have some major flaws, firstly it is about thirty minutes too long and could easily have stood a little trimming. Second, Jack Davenport's performance is abysmal for what is a small but pivotal role. Geoffrey Rush does ok as do Kiera Knightley and Orlando Bloom but they all blown off the screen by the mighty Johnny Depp. Basing his performance on early 70s Keith Richards Depp struts around the screen and makes the film his own, he is helped by the fact that he gets most of the film's best lines but nevertheless it is difficult to imagine anyone but Depp pulling this off. It is his most demented, brilliant performance since Fear And Loathing In Las Vegas and one of the best of his career.This film could easily have failed. It is a summer blockbuster based on an amusement park ride and as such normally the kind of film I wouldn't even bother to see, but, it has such a great sense of mindless fun that it proves enchanting. See it, if only for Depp.</fullReview>

		<username>nolanjwerner (nolanjwerner@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>I thought this movie would be terrible but...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Okay, when I first saw the poster and saw the names of Gore "I turned Ringu in to a movie with lots of loud noises because Americans can not be scared by anything remotely psychological" Verbinski and Jerry "Kangaroo Jack and lots of movies with big explosions" Bruckheimer on the credits, I was sceptical (a variant spelling of skeptical, not related to a septic tank) but as it turns out the movie is pretty good. It is a fun summer popcorn movie and despite some large plot holes, turns out to be one of the better films of the summer (well of the "popcorn" movies).Orlando Bloom is Legolas without pointy ears and with a sword instead of a bow (but the girls dig him so I will not go in to copious detail about his mediocre acting, he fills the part). Keira Knightley is just hot (she would be drop dead gorgeous even without the accent but is on the top of my list with Fleur Saville and Antonia Prebble because of it) and legal (but just barely). Geoffrey Rush is lost in the character, one of the signs of a really good actor, though I have to say that he did not really add anything special that no other actor could have, a shame for such a talented guy. The rest of the cast are also excellent and the dialogue is good and tolerable even at the worst of times.The special effects in the film are excellent, I only wish that all films loaded with special effects would be this good. Special Effects are there to ENHANCE the plot and the acting, not to take the place of it.I am going to finish this review by raving about Johnny Depp because he really was the reason the film was so good. I literally do not think the film would have been half as good with anyone else in the role (well maybe Daniel Day-Lewis). He creates a unique and engaging character and endears himself to you, a hard task for the disowned gay son of Captain Morgan. Johnny Depp has proven once again why he is among the elite inner circle of great actors (well mine anyway, along with Ed Norton, Kenneth Branagh, Don Cheadle, Daniel Day-Lewis, Judi Dench, Forrest Whitaker, Brian Cox, Kevin Spacey, Al Pacino, Robert DeNiro, Phillip Seymour Hoffman and probably a few I am forgetting unfortunately, my apologies to them).It works best on the big screen, so go to the second run theatre and see it for two bucks for Johnny Depp if nothing else.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Depp owns this movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I am a huge Johnnie Depp fan. As far back as _Edward Scissorhands_ and _Crybaby_ he was making risky career choices and carrying them off with his incredible talent. However, although I knew I would be going to see _Pirates of the Caribbean_ the day it opened, I had my doubts. After all, this is a movie based on a ride. Not based on a book, not even based on a true story, based on a theme park ride! And talented though he is, Depp has made some less than wonderful movies (_The Astronaut's Wife_ springs to mind). But I went anyway, because it has Johnnie Depp, not to mention Legolas and the Marquis de Sade. And the movie was wonderful. But it clearly would not have been so without Johnnie Depp. The other actors were fine, particularly Geoffrey Rush and Orlando Bloom. The script was sufficiently quirky that the film probably would have been fairly entertaining despite the overlong and repetitive battle scenes and the overdone jokes between the two sailors (not to mention the overdoner jokes between the two pirates). The special effects were good, the photography beautiful and the music excellent, but it nevertheless doesn't add up to anything more than a pretty good summer flick. Until you add Johnny Depp. His Crazed Queen of the Spanish Main is simply brilliant, and it turns POTC into the best flick of the summer and one of the best of the year. I hear they are already filming a sequel; I have my doubts about that too, having seen XMen 2, Matrix 2, Terminator 3... But then, none of those films had Johnnie Depp.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-08-03</date>
		<username>Ben Burgraff (cariart)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Fun Pirate Saga!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Now, I'll admit I loved PIRATES, but it is not without faults, the greatest being, IT'S TOO LONG! Will SOMEBODY tell Jerry Bruckheimer that a feature film doesn't HAVE to be over two hours and fifteen minutes long? A half hour trimmed would have tightened the plot, kept the audience jumping at the climaxes (and not for the bathroom), and increased the revenue, as another showtime could be squeezed in each day.That being said, there is a lot to like about the film. A truly good pirate movie MUST obey certain guidelines: a swashbuckling hero, an equally strong damsel, a truly dastardly villain, a great climactic duel, a romance, at least one major sea battle and city plundering scene, LOTS of pirate lore, and respect for the time frame of the film (NO lapses into 20th or 21st century jargon or technology, for the sake of plot or humor). Hollywood's last major pirate effort, CUTTHROAT ISLAND, had Gena Davis as a distaff hero, which was acceptable (Maureen O'Hara had played a swashbuckler in several 40s-50s films), and Frank Langella as the villain, which was inspired casting...but Matthew Modine was so wimpish a leading man that the romance between him and Davis looked ridiculous, and Davis evolved into a near caricature, to fill the void...and the film descended into present-day campiness, which was the kiss of death.Director Gore Verbinski, and writers Ted Elliott, Terry Rossio, Stuart Beattie, and Jay Wolpert clearly did their homework for PIRATES, and admirably filled each pirate movie requirement. Two heroes swash their way through the film; Johnny Depp is the picturebook pirate, complete with outrageous attire, a braided beard, eye makeup, a drunken swagger, and the best damn' Keith Richards impersonation I've ever seen; Orlando Bloom is the heroic, Errol Flynn-like buccaneer, out to rescue his damsel, and full of lofty ideals. Eighteen-year-old Keira Knightley is the heroine, and while her acting skills are average, at best, she shows a lot of spunk (and cleavage), and positively glows, onscreen. The villain is another inspired piece of casting; Geoffrey Rush, while not as menacing as Frank Langella, has a ball as the snarling yet world-weary Pirate leader. As for the pirate crews (there are two), they are perfect; you have guys with hooks and peg legs, barbarians straight out of MOBY DICK, even a parrot and a monkey as sidekicks, all hankering for rum, riches, and victims to 'walk the plank'. That one crew is all cursed, and reveal themselves to be skeletal, decomposing corpses under the full moon only increases their nasty perfection!The film borrows heavily from THE CRIMSON PIRATE, TREASURE ISLAND, SWASHBUCKLER, Universal Pictures' 40s B-movie pirate flicks, and even a few Hammer horror features of the early 60s, but it all fits together fairly seamlessly. Still, the excessive length would be a fatal flaw, were it not for Johnny Depp's physical and verbal presense. He is the glue that holds everything together, and he is VERY much up to the task! Whenever the film starts to drag, Depp has some bit of 'business' that is hilarious, and keeps things rolling.I won't delve into the plot (cursed gold, kidnappings, a gallows scene...pretty standard pirate stuff), but I will say that you could do a LOT worse than PIRATES in this season of overblown sequels and underwhelming originals.Go to the bathroom before you go to the theater, and ENJOY!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-08-03</date>
		<username>gwendolyn_of_slytherin</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Excellent and Stylish</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I've seen this movie once, and I'll not rest until I've seen it again. To make myself more frank, my sister has (rather unwillingly) seen this movie four times in one week, and I'm jealous. I loved Pirates of the Caribbean the Ride at Disneyland/world as a kid, and when I heard about this movie, I couldn't wait to see it. Opening night my whole family went, and we were absolutely enthralled.The opening scene with Johnny Depp is absolutely hilarious, and he makes a wonderful pirate, as, "That's *Captain* Jack Sparrow". He should play a pirate more often. He is a brilliant mixture of funny, strange, and exotic all in one, and keeps on dazzling throughout the entire film. Geoffrey Rush as Captain Barbossa makes an awesome villain, eccentric and quirky enough not to be scary, but when he and his crew turn into a bunch of skeletons, it still was chilling. Orlando Bloom is an adorable Will Turner, showing a funny side but easily acting as a rival to Depp for attention on screen (though the award would go to Depp, he was beyond amazing). I was also very impressed with Keira Knightley as Elizabeth Swann - she was a tough heroine, didn't act like a girly screamer, and was funny as well.The plot is good, the acting great in Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl. Though rated PG-13 (one of the firsts for Disney), I would definitely call it a great family film for the older kids. I wouldn't be surprised if they made further adventures of the Pirates, and the best part is that it wouldn't be a sequel, just the continuing adventure.Go see Pirates of the Caribbean (again) Today!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-07-31</date>
		<username>friendtalk_2000</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>See it for Johnny Depp</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>For a movie based off a Disneyland ride, this is a very pleasant surprise indeed. This movie manages to stay kid-friendly without /feeling/ kid-friendly - always a good thing. I know I hate to be patronized. "Pirates" also makes us appreciate pirates again, when it could have so easily failed; when was the last time there was a good pirate movie? I can't even remember, but it doesn't matter because this one is, amazingly, good. Orlando Bloom is de-elfed here, bland but passable as the romantic lead, and Keira Knightley continues to show her solidity as an actress, whether it be here or in the wonderful "Bend It Like Beckham." Geoffrey Rush makes us, if not sympathize with, at least understand where his villain is coming from, lending his subtle touch with emotion to counter every "yarr" and "matey."But, of course, the real star here is Johnny Depp. Let's use a few cliches: Wildly charismatic, explosively talented - any others? Thousands, thousands, because Johnny Depp is surprising us once again with his choices as an actor and his considerable depth of emotion and range. Jack Sparrow is a fascinating character wholly because of Depp's willingness to seize the character and make it totally his own. Wearing inexplicable but attractive eyeliner, swaying and gesticulating drunkenly, Depp says each line with an originality that brings the script above and beyond where we could have reasonably expected it. Mildly amusing jokes are hilarious in his hands; an essential undercurrent of emotion and reality crackles in between his gold teeth and his swashbuckler's boots. He makes this movie. He drags it forward with the force of a hurricane. And that is, for the most part, why this pleasant high-seas adventure is worth the eight bucks.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-07-30</date>
		<username>Nicole Summers</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Wonderful! It proves part of Hollywood wrong!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Pirates Of the Caribbean is one of the best movies I've ever seen. There is a saying in Hollywood that goes out to Adult actors,"Be careful of scenes that include children and animals, because they'll always steal the attention away from you." Well, now add Captain Jack Sparrow,(or Johnny Depp)to that saying. This movie would not have been so wonderful if anyone else had been Jack. Mr. Depp is a truly talented actor, and it shows with evertything he does. From the lines to the simple body language, he made it all his own, and you could tell that this was a fun movie to make by watching the effort in every scene. I hope the sequel is as wonderful.SPOILERS------ To clear up a misunderstanding: Jack IS NOT cursed through the entire movie. Thyat's why he eats and drinks through out the film. Jack was abandoned before the pirates were cursed. If you notice, he's in the moonlight several times in the film, and he doesn't change. That's because he's not cursed. He steals the coin at the end because he knows he's going to fight Barbossa, and didn't want to die. If you notice, when he tosses Will the coin, he slits his hand so HIS BLOOD IS ALSO ON THE COIN. That's what the curse needed, blood from everyone who stole a coin. And even if he hadn't taken the coin, he still would have been cursed, because he doesn't repay the blood.----------------- The movie is quite long, but worth while and certainly entertaining. 10/10 and two thumbs up!!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-30</date>
		<username>Dan Heller (argv@danheller.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Fun for the whole family, whether you've been on the ride or not.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Ahoy Maties! Grab your swords and board the dreaded pirate ship, the Black Pearl, and sail back in time to when you were a kid at Disneyland, going through the boat ride, `Pirates of the Caribbean.' Whatever your imagination could have conjured up, it couldn't possibly compare to the wonderment, fun and childhood excitement that the live-action film delivers today. This is, in many ways, the perfect film, because it not only does exactly what it intends, but it does so without a hint of corniness, overdone computer graphics, sappy dialog, or boring plot line.Sure, the movie is just for fun, and you can enjoy it for what it is if you go into the theater with the same sense of fun that you'd have going into the ride at Disney parks. In fact, just about every scene from the robotic namesake ride (that's over 30 years old) is featured conspicuously in the film, causing giggles of nostalgia from the audience.The plot is classic fairy tale formula for a Swashbucklin' Pirate story that involves pirates, fair maidens, a hero to save her, royalty, and an intricate intertwining of relationships that make things oh so juicy. Here, Johnny Depp leads the pack as Jack Sparrow, a lone pirate on the Caribbean Sea, looking for his lost ship, the Black Pearl. It'd been commandeered years earlier by Captain Barbossa (Geoffrey Rush) who'd lead a mutiny against him. For Sparrow to get his ship back, he must commandeer one of his own, so he picks one from the Royal British Navy. But first, he must cross swords with a young sword maker, Will Turner, played by Orlando Bloom.In the meantime, Barbossa has his own agenda: to break a curse set upon the crew after they stole ancient Aztec gold artifacts. To do this, they must return the gold, plus spill the blood from a descendant of the original captain of the Black Pearl that pirated the loot in the first place. Through misidentification, they capture Elizabeth Swann, played by Keira Knightley, who is subsequently kidnapped. In this scene, Geoffrey Rush delivers a brilliant monologue about his plight as a cursed pirate.At this point, Turner and Sparrow set out as partners to find the Black Pearl: Turner wants to save the girl, and Sparrow wants to get his ship back. Over the course of the film, as secrets are revealed and events unfold, the tension and action builds to a rewarding and pleasingly climactic ending.Essentially, the movie has it all: cartoony sword-fighting, skeletons drinking rum, dream-like scenery that captures the spirit of the dark, imaginary world of pirates swinging between ships, ladies having to walk the plank, and valiant heroes saving them. With the youthful target audience in mind, a more cynical viewer looking for a more intense or less `comedic' tone might be disappointed; similarly, an overly protective parent might be concerned for their youngsters' fear factor at some special effects, but these are all phantom concerns. `Pirates of the Caribbean' as a great mid-summer hit that's sure to please the whole family.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-29</date>

		<date>2003-07-28</date>
		<username>Ron Broadfoot</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Anyone who doesn't like this movie can walk the plank!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Pirates of The Caribbean" is one of the best big-screen blockbusters of the summer. There's lots of action from start to finish, and the movie is helped by great performances from a mostly British cast (with the exception of Johnny Depp). It's actually everything that Steven Spielberg's "Hook" should have been, but wasn't. After seeing this movie, you will probably never look at the ride at Disneyland in the same way again!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>K-crisp</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>my comments</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Spoiler alert I've seen mixed reviews on the movie. Some are quick to say that it has no real direction, but i noticed some intricacies and subtleties that, although not really bringing the plot together any more (which can hardly be done at all),give the movie a subtle sort of repitition, but not in a boring way. I'm about ready to give some examples of things to look for when you go back and see it, rent it, purchase it, whatever; so if you wish for the movie's contents to be revealed only upon your viewing it, read this no more because i'm giving insight into the movie. When dealing with the captain Barbossa, it seemed that apples were focused on quite a bit. I took it as the apple was sort of a symbol of what he had to get back by breaking the curse. it was the symbol of what he could enjoy being human again. So when Jack Sparrow proposes his idea into barbossa's telescope, he's eating the nice shiny apple. It seemed to be Jack's clever way of rubbing it in and reminding him of why he's there, while also saying, "look what i can do that you can't." And also when barbossa is killed, the apple is there. As he dies, it rolls out of his pocket or something and shows the sort of irony about not being able to enjoy life after the curse because his death soon followed.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-25</date>
		<username>Michael Plewa (michael-plewa@uiowa.edu)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Bad trailer...But GOOD Movie!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I remember once I had this uncanny knack for predicting the merit of a film by its trailer. A few years ago, I was proved wrong with Legally Blonde, a delightful nugget. Pirates of the Carribean, I'm sad to say, deeply misleads in the preview. For one, the trailer showcases, by far, the least funny line in a film full of extremely funny lines. The upper-class British girl smacks a Pirate saying, "You like pain? Try wearing a corset." I'm thinking, "They put that in the preview to whet your appetite? Just imagine how much worse it gets." I knew this movie would do well financially, considering the producer and the cast and the appeal of seeing Pirates swashbuckle once again, I mean, Jerry Bruckheimer couldn't lose money if he lost a leg and was in a butt-kicking contest. So I also knew people would see this movie, a lot of people. But that trailer nagged at me all the way in to the screening, thinking about how many not-funny one-liners we'd endure in the course of seeing all these stereotypes go against type.And then Johnny Depp comes on screen. He is proudly standing in the crow's nest of his mighty ship, and the film is immediately off to the right start in the very next shot. I don't want to ruin it, and maybe the guys making the trailer didn't want to either. There's something to be said for not laying your cards on the table early, like so many movies do in their marketing campaign. It only took one cut to melt down the icy walls I had erected in my critical mind, and I was immediately sold. This movie is by far the best example of comedy, action, and good genre film-making of the summer. I say genre film-making because it is very in line with the classic Pirate archetypes. Except, of course, for Johnny Depp. His performance, sans the brilliant script he's given, would seem anachronistic, out of the realm of possibility for this era and tone of film-making. He'd seem too hip, too funny, too above it all while wallowing in the filth. However, Depp serves as both the audience's ambassador to the story, and the story's greatest asset. In one of the funniest lines in the movie, Orlando Bloom's Will Turner and the first mate are discussing how Depp was betrayed and then stranded to die on a deserted island. When Will asks how he escaped, the first mate says he tethered rope around sea turtles and made a raft. Predictably, Will asks where he got the rope, and then in a fearsome low-angle, Depp bellows, "With human hair...from my back." We cut away immediately to the next scene, and the rest of the film plays much the same. When a movie has four or five truly funny lines or moments, it will milk those for all their worth. Literally, they'll make a running gag. But "Pirates" runs out of room for the old jokes with all the new jokes, making this film nearly a laugh-a-minute action comedy. I say nearly only because of the brilliant action sequences, that are still light on their toes, but exciting too. There are a few running jokes, the biggest being that Pirates are really despicable people, and when we think they'll outgrow their greed and become true heroes, they wallow reluctantly in their cowardice. In one great scene, Keira Knightley's Elizabeth leads the charge to take Depp's loyal crew to rescue their beloved captain. They aren't following. She beckons with the reason that Depp would come back for them. In the next cut, she's rowing alone. "Bloody Pirates!" Depp, therefore, is the greatest pirate anyone's ever seen. He plays every angle, but chooses the heroic when there's nothing better to do. But everyone in the film has their moment of true heroism. They don't do things that seem like the old-hat mode of turning unlikely heroes into heroes. All the cowards in "Pirates" remain cowards, some endearing and some villainous, and all the heroes are truly heroic, even when they have their priorities out of whack. That's why you'll grow to like everybody, because they're all really good at what they do.I will go see the sequel, and I may be disappointed, but at least I won't be disappointed until the movie's over, because the trailer will mislead the uninitiated into thinking it's another Bruckheimer explosion music video, and it is anything but.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-25</date>
		<username>Cal24</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Filled with Action, Adventure and Laughs.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Pirates of The Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl, Starring Johnny Depp and Orlando Bloom is a must see movie this summer, and is easily the best Pirate film ever made. Despite its PG-13 rating (mostly for violence), this movie is entertaining and fun for people of all ages. Johnny Depp is tremendous in his role as Captain Jack Sparrow, and depicts this pirate character in a way that no other actor could have. He is truly remarkable. Orlando Bloom lacks the charm that Depp carries, yet he too plays his role well as Wil Turner. Keira Knightley from Bend it like Beckham also stars along with Geoffrey Rush.While the movie is long, 146 minutes, it moves along at a good pace. The audience seemed to get a bit restless only after the movie had climaxed and continued on for another 20 minutes. While I believe the movie could have been shorter, Depp kept my attention to the very end.While many movies this summer such as Bad Boys II, Hulk, and Terminator III advertise with action and violence, this movie has action, with humor and good fun on the side. The cast has already signed on for a sequel. I really liked this movie. If your looking for pure entertainment, with no thinking or worrying, go see "Pirates". It is a painless, sit back and relax movie. ****/5 stars.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>tigrrbaby</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>the kind of disney movie that made disney a household name</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I will mainly be echoing what the others have said, but I wanted to be sure and say it too, to add my vote.This movie excels at ENTERTAINING.Without sex, gore, potty jokes, or a single cuss word*, it is romantic, exciting, humorous, and witty. (Kind of in the tradition of Princess Bride, in the sense of it being a true FAMILY movie, only POTC is about 200% more exciting and adventurous, and a bit less cheesy).The movie is 2.5 hours long, but there is not a single point at which I (or any of the friends who watched it with me) felt as though we had been there a long time or as though the plot was slowing down. It wasn't until we left the theater that we realized how long we'd been entertained!The music is great- I have been searching everywhere for a soundtrack or score, with no success.Johnny Depp was perfect as Jack Sparrow, the pirate with a screw loose. I can't imagine anyone else in the role- when I try to, I think "they would ruin it!" Orlando and Kiera are not hard to look at, and each of them has moments that would make the opposite sex weak in the knees.The lord of the rings movies, all our superhero movies, the star wars movies have all raised the bar to a very high level for special effects. However, the effects in this movie WERE convincing and, in addition, they were interesting! Several times, you could tell that the action was choreographed in such a way to show off the effects, and at those times, the scenes were absolutely picturesque - the type that you'd like to put up on your wall.Like just about everyone else who has posted here, I immediately decided, while leaving the theater, that I will be going back to see it again, the $8 per show fee notwithstanding.This is an excellent movie that I will own as soon as it is available on DVD, and I will continue to recommend it to everyone I know.Just see it for yourself!*(The word Bejesus is used, as is the word Hell in the literal sense; that is, referring to the location Hell; I don't consider these cuss words)</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-22</date>
		<username>The 14th Warrior</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A pleasant surprise of the highest order</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My expectations for this movie - or its score, for that matter - were not too high. In fact, let's face it: I expected it to suck very, very hard. Fortunately I was pleasantly surprised, nay blown away even. I haven't had this much fun at an action/adventure film since The Mummy. From the astoundingly lush sets and costumes to the beautiful cinematography, to the satisfyingly quotable dialogue, this movie had everything the blusteringly swashbuckling connoisseur could hope for. But what really makes it such a tremendously enjoyable experience is the fantastic acting. Johnny Depp's performance as Jack Sparrow once again proves that he is one of the finest actors of our generation - boastful, swaggering and deliciously over the top he is never boring to watch. Geoffrey Rush is no less excellent as the dreadful undead pirate Captain LeChuck, who kidnaps the beautiful governor's daughter Elaine Marley (Bend it Like Beckham's Keira Knightley) to undo the curse he and his shipmates suffer from. Also great: Orlando Bloom as Elaine's childhood friend Guybrush Threepwood, a dashing (as opposed to merely runny) blacksmith turned pirate. It's all very much The Mummy meets Cutthroat Island, though done with a lot more skill and panache. My second favorite film of the year so far (after Finding Nemo). I can only hope that Wild Wild West II: The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen will turn out to be equally superb.As for the score, Klaus Badelt (and six other composers, amongst them Jimmy Doodle and Steve Jabalabomsky) once again proves that while he may not be a very original composer, he is superb at filtering other people's work. He distilled the best of Gladiator and Muppet Treasure Island, filtered out all of the annoying Lisa Gerrard whining and cheap synthesizers, added a bit of K-19, Drop Zone and Goblin (the cue accompanying the initial appearance of the Black Pearl was quite reminiscent of their wonderful work for Argento's Suspiria) and mixed it all up, resulting in a marvelous little film music stew. It's all the MV nutrients without the fats! I might even get the CD, if only for that fabulously re-orchestrated version of the Drop Zone trailer music!Satisfying? Yes. But since this is one of the finest adventure films I've seen in ages, I still cannot help but lament that Silvestri didn't write this score. Or Goldsmith. Or Shearmur. Or Debney. Or Doyle. It would have kicked Cutthroat Island, The Mummy Returns AND Sinbad into oblivion.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>This movie is undoubtedly a hit. WARNING SPOILER</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>WARNING (SPOILER IN THIS POSTING) This movie is a masterpiece that is surprisingly produced by Disney. I'm not saying that Disney produces terrible movies. I just haven't seen a Disney movie with violence like this, or a rating like this in a while. I have noticed that in the past few years, Disney has put out movies that have parts that are directed to the adult viewers. Anyway, "Pirates of the Caribbean" is a movie with much promise. It takes the viewer into another time and place that seems so real. At the same time that the film came out, the video game also came out. This move was directed to help the movie, since the game has no correlation to the movie, except that you encounter the Black Pearl and the female lead role in the film narrates the game. Anyway, Depp and Bloom gave fantastic performances. Depp did really well as the witty Captain Sparrow looking to get even, while saving his own skin. Bloom fit his part very well. But Rush did extremely well as the Captain of the Black Pearl. I have yet to see him fit his character in a while. He did well in "House on Haunted Hill." The special effects in this film are amazing. Of course nothing too surprising from Disney. I have to admit that the fight in the cave in the end was very well done. When Rush and Depp are fighting in the cave, they jump from dark to moonlight. The effect of them turning from human to undead was one of the best special effects that I have seen in a long time. Most movies that try something like this, generally have the camera farther back so that they do not have to change the character's appearances as many times as this film did. The pirates in the film were amazing. Each one of them had their own characteristics that were obvious to the viewers. Overall, this movie is a have to see for people looking for a ride that doesn't let go.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Depp is classic</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Out of all the summer movies of 2003, "Pirates" definetely qualifies for the best. I think this film maybe the first good pirate movie since god knows when. It seems like a brilliant mixture of action/adventure/comedy/fantasy/thriller with some horrific pirate skeleton scenes. Now on the acting. This movie couldn't of done too much for Orlando Bloom's career as he is the most boring character in my opinion. Keira Knightley definetely had an interesting character that helped the movie very much. Geoffrey Rush was brilliant, although this movie probably mostly helped Johnny Depp, whose character was Jack Sparrow. Depp was definetely right for the part, and he was just so funny in most of his scenes. This is definetely a movie worth seeing in the summer, as is LXG, Terminator 3, Finding Nemo, Johnny English, and (even though I haven't seen it) 28 Days Later. Here are a list of movies to stay away from: at 5: The Hulk. at 4: Charlie's Angels 2. at 3: Legally Blonde 2. at 2: Sinbad. at 1: From Justin To Kelly.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I really had no intentions of going to see Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl. In my mind I wrote the film off as a flop last year when it was first announced. Summer 2003 rolls around and Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl gained some of the best reviews for any movie this summer, so alas I thought I would go and see what the big deal was. I have to say Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl really surpised since I don't really go for Disney flicks, but director Gore Verbinski and producer Jerry Bruckheimer have made a film full of action that anyone can enjoy. I have to say that Johnny Depp as Jack Sparrow, Geoffrey Rush as Captain Barbossa and the lovely Keira Knightley as Elizabeth Swann all make the film work with their performances. Orlando Bloom is ok in the movie but his role could have been played by anyone. Still a great ride and a lot of fun.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-17</date>
		<username>indigo7699</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>More than just a Disney ride turned into a movie!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>On hearing the premise of this movie, I was determined to avoid it at all costs. Then I found out who was in the cast, read some reviews, and decided to give it a go despite the risk of having to sit through a fluffy, Disnified film.Granted, I love pirate movies, and the dearth of good ones lately has left me looking for a ray of hope. This movie has more than redeemed the genre.While occasionally nodding to the popular Disney ride, this film stands completely on its own. The plot, while somewhat convoluted (WHICH ship are they on now?), provided a fun backdrop to show of the story's characters. Geoffrey Rush plays an oddly likeable villian as Barbarossa, the captain of the ghost pirates of the buccaneer ship the Black Pearl. Orlando Bloom's naive Will Turner was the sweet and likeable hero (though perhaps not the brightest coin in the chest). Keira Knightley's Elizabeth Swan was loveably feisty (she knows how to use a musket! You go, girl!). As Governor Swan, Jonathan Pryce keeps it light enough that we don't hate the character for being a snob--and his encounter with the arm that wouldn't die is priceless. And, last but certainly not least, Johnny Depp plays Mad Captain Jack Sparrow so convincingly he could have carried the movie himself, creating a character you're never really sure is quite sober or sane, but definitely wily and always fascinating. The special effects for the movie were fairly good, especially during an underwater march of the undead pirates. The dialogue in the movie escapes being trite due to the talent of the cast, and instead comes across as familiar but funny. For you action fans, there's plenty to love: Orlando Bloom revisits his sword-fighting talent in several scenes, and Johnny Depp gets to put his athletic talents to the test while jumping and swinging from ship to ship all the way across the Spanish Main. If you're willing to give this movie a chance, I highly recommend catching it before it leaves the big screen. It will still be fun on DVD, but it's worth the price of a ticket.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-16</date>
		<username>Jack the Ripper1888</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Disney rises to new heights...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The thing that is so big about PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: THE CURSE OF THE BLACK PEARL (other than its ten-word title and it's 2 and a half hour running time) is the fact that this is a hit. I mean, a movie about pirates, that has a lot of skeleton guys walking around. It's perfect for the little kids and its not been plunged to the horrid depths of being so stupid that adults (yes, you small minded adults) will even like it. Kiera Knightly is hott (for the guys), Orlando Bloom is a heart-throb for the girls, and Johnny Depp wears heavy mascara. How can this movie fail?Well, there are so many changes in the plot, so many twists and turns-- this is a direct result of the writer not knowing what to do and not knowing where he was going with the script. Nevertheless, the film does have a sort of creepy, moody feel to it that helps it become nostalgic and just kind of has the words "Box Office Smash" written all over it. Granted, half of its audience members are probably people who are just wasting time before THE LEAGUE OF EXTRAORDINARY GENTLEMEN comes out, this film still stands on its own. Director Gore Virbinski again returns, getting better all the time. His last attempt THE RING was an extreme hit but many people are getting quite bored with it now (sequel time maybe?). Hopefully Virbinski will only continue his trend of gradually getting better with each new film.The graphics are well done and the film contains several moments of eerie horror and thrilling action sequences. The humor comes in bounds (again, trying to amuse the little kiddies) and Johnny Depp acts very 'action-hero', kinda like Brendan Fraser's role in THE MUMMY. He still does very well. The films stands on its own, has loads of originality and is a hit. It won't stay that way forever though.PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: THE CURSE OF THE BLACK PEARL gets 4/5.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-07-15</date>
		<username>rancidlover</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Super Fun, Super Long</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you have around 2 1/2 hours of free time, and you want to spend your time wisely you should go check out Pirates of the Caribbean. Johnny Depp (Jack Sparrow) was the one who saved this movie. Seriously, without Johnny I probably would have either fallen asleep or left. Sure, Orlando Bloom (Will Turner) did a great job leaving his elfish persona behind and performing in a role unlike what we have seen him in before, but he really did not make this movie. One performance that I did enjoy, although I wasn't totally blown away, was the performance by Keira Knightley (Elizabeth Swann). Her character seemed to mesh well with Orlando's character. Plus, Orlando and Keira seemed like they really enjoyed their roles and had fun. Geoffrey Rush (Barbossa) did absolutely nothing for me, and the character the Governor (Jonathan Price) was not up to par with the other actors indeed. All in all, the storyline is pretty awesome. Unrealistic most of the time, it still is fun. I had fun watching this movie, even though towards the end I wish it would have just ended sooner. I was tired. Who can blame me? Also, some of the storyline was pretty predictable. But what do you expect from a movie based on a ride from a theme park?</fullReview>

		<username>freakishbiscuit</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Thrilling, beginning to end, much better than expected.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl" is a movie based upon the Walt Disney ride "Pirates of the Caribbean". Though it may seem a tad different at first glance, seeing as Disney is creating a movie after the ride when it would be expected to be seen in the opposite order, this film is exceptionally well done. If you enjoy the ride, then you will adore the movie. Almost every scene from the ride appears, even if it is very brief, within the movie (the auction is the only one noticed to have gone missing by two of the three of my party this evening). The song that those who have gone on the ride would recognize appears first and makes a strange yet interesting beginning. The special effects during this film were exceptional and seamless. Not to mention the casting... Johnny Depp as Jack Sparrow was a perfect match. This movie keeps you guessing the entire time and holds your attention (even if you have found yourself in front of a noisy bunch of teenagers). This film is one of the best I've seen in theaters all year.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-14</date>
		<username>ghlist7876</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>What not to expect</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Let's face it, any movie based on an amusement park ride that people only go on to get out of the blistering heat is not going to be as deep as Citizen Kane. Do not bother with the holes in the plotline, as there are more of those than a trainload of Swiss cheese, but rather focus on the fact that the digital engineers at Disney were able to study the Errol Flynn movies and recreate them using the latest in imaging techniques. The result is a mindbending display of scenery and swordfights all acted out with a cast of quality performers, who seem to be plucked right from the pages of what we perceive to be accurate history. It plays right to the imagination, and I loved it. Johnny Depp steals the show as the swishbuckling androgenous pirate, and the supporting cast was selected with an eye on keeping the right mix of wisdom, youth, characterization, and sex appeal. Especially loved the scene of the drunken revelers on the island of Tortuga, as it was a living snapshot of the theme park ride.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

The only problem is that the movie is about 30 minutes too long. They could have shortened some of the fight scenes or eliminated at least one. The rest of the movie is comical swashbuckling fun. We'd all recommend it without reservation!!!!!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-13</date>
		<username>bsdryn</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Action, comedy, effects. Great summer fun.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>So many cool movies come out during the summer, but for some reason, Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl was one of the films I was most interested in. It just looked so fun and stylish and cool. The pirate theme is too underused in movies. So anyway, I got to see it on opening day, and it was as good as I had hoped. Here's a few reasons you should go see Pirates of the Caribbean, me bucko: 1) Johnny Deep. Ya gotta hand it to Depp for giving his character Captain Jack Sparrow such a unique personality. He fumbles into a lot of bad luck (and jail cells), but is always able to use his charm and skill to get out of it. His body language and style of speech are awesome, which makes for a very memorable character. The rest of the cast is great too, in particular Geoffrey Rush as the cruel pirate Captain Barbossa. But it's Johnny Deep who makes this movie. 2) Undead pirates! With all due respect to Ray Harryhausen's sword-fighting skeletons in Jason and the Argonauts, this cursed crew has to be the coolest bunch of skeletons I've seen on screen. It's an impressive effect when they move in and out of moonlight. Must have been a nightmare for ILM animators, with so much detail... bones and hair and tattered clothing. And then to stick dozens of these skeletons in fights with live actors? Wow. I actually would have enjoyed seeing more scenes with the moonlit monsters. But ye scurvy dogs who don't like too much CG stuff, will be glad to know the movie has plenty of other swashbuckling action that doesn't rely on animated effects. With a running time of around 2 hours, 20 minutes, there's enough time for a little of everything. 3) Comedy. Pirates of the Caribbean isn't an all out comedy, but there's a boatload of humor. Especially from Jack Sparrow and some of Barbossa's bungling crew. I was laughing quite a bit, either from actual jokes, visual gags, or just the absurd situations. It's really a witty script. The story isn't all that complicated, but I liked the way they revealed things as they go, so the plot isn't totally predictable. I hear it's the first Disney film to get a PG-13 rating... I assume because the skeletal pirate violence could give little kids nightmares. But the rest is good family fun so I think this should appeal to a wide audience. So check it out, me hearties. Yo-ho!</fullReview>
	</review>

Kinda goes in the face of the ultra sexist, artistically bankrupt, presumptous pieces of summer mindless garbage like, among many, "Charlie's Angels Full Throttle" and "Legally Blonde II". 	<review>
		<date>2003-07-12</date>
		<username>AmericanPanascope</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>THIS MOVIE KICKS BUTT - One of the 5 best so far this year!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I just got back from seeing Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl, and I am awestruck. I was just at Disneyland on Monday, so the ride this movie was based on was fresh in my mind. I liked that they worked in the bit from the ride with the imprisoned pirates trying to tempt the dog that holds the keys to their cell.The performances were amazing, especially by Geoffrey Rush and Johnny Depp. Jack Sparrow's introduction was brilliant. Depp was perfect in every way as Sparrow, right down to his drunken swagger. The only one miscast here in my opinion was Jonathan Pryce - he will always be Elliot Carver from Tomorrow Never Dies in my mind. Everyone else was excellent.The visual effects are extraordinary. They aren't overly exploited and they don't look fake, unlike some effects films (can you say Hulk?).Gore Verbinski is one of the most versatile and talented directors out there. Every movie he's made (except MouseHunt) has been enjoyable and entertaining. The cinematography was totally engrossing and beautiful, but for God's sakes STOP SHOOTING MOVIES LIKE THIS IN SUPER-35!!! My parents kept asking me if the movie was unfocused because of the definition loss. SHOOT ANAMORPHIC!!!Anyway....where was I.... Oh yeah, the MUSIC! The best thing about this movie was the music. Produced under the supervision of the brilliant genius Hans Zimmer, Klaus Badelt's score is the best I've heard on a movie this year.This is one of the five best movies thus far this year, joining the ranks with the likes of The Matrix Reloaded and Terminator 3.9.5/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-12</date>
		<username>Noir187</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>An Action-Master-Piece? I never would have thought...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>PotC caught me by surprise. The few trailers I had seen for the movie made it look interesting (pirate are neat) but hadn't done much to impress me; they marketed it as an non-stop action movie (not that those can't be entertaining). However, it's so much more than that. Johnny Depp is a highly capable actor (even when he is in some less than capable movies) who can hold the stage well. However, in this film, he utterly dominates it as Jack Sparrow (that's Captain Jack Sparrow). He really throws himself into the character's role and it works with such ease; he comes off as one of the best anti-heroes I ever seen: a swashbuckling and devilishly charming pirate whose charisma makes you root for him the entire time. If the rest of the movie had been terirble it would still be worth seeing for this man's performance. Orlando Bloom works well here (though you still want to think of him as Legolas) alongside Depp. His seriousness counters just as well as his swordplay against Depp's roguish charm. His character is well rounded and good but he comes off more as a sidekick as Depp's acting places him in the background. Geoffrey Rush is an amazing actor. If you've seen the Tailor of Panama or Quills (amongst his newer works) you'd know this. His portrayal as the cursed Captain of the Black Pearl truly reminded me of his performance as the Marquis de Sade in Quills: dark, brooding and disturbingly charismatic. He would steal the show if it were not for Depp's power. Keira Knightley works well as the damsel in distress but she's much more than that in this film. As a newcomer, she'll make a good career for herself. The CGI effects of the skeletons is magnificent. They blend in well with the scenes and, though you realize the use of CGI, it doesn't stand out in the crowd. The cinematography was well done and made the action scenes creative as well as entertaining. The choreography of such scenes was also top-notch and the swordplay was much more impressive than that in the latest Bond film. Too much good stuff can be said about this movie. It is the best movie I've seen this summer and possibly the best movie of this year that I've seen (I still need to check out Better Luck Tomorrow). All in all, Depp deserves an Oscar nod (at least) for this role. It's one of his career's best.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-07-12</date>
		<username>MidnightWarrior</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Step away from the box office...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I've actually been reading reviews for this film and have to admit that I'm quite surprized. While I do have to admit that there were some truly worthy scenes and the directing was absolutly superb, I left the theater disappointed.First of all the ending is boring, predictable, cheesy, overplayed and used out in hollywood films today. Secondly, the movie is too long. Lots of people walked out because some parts of the movie were extremely slow and/or kept on dragging on. On the subject of dragging on, this film was very violent for a Disney movie. Now I've got nothing against violence as I'm looking forward to some upcoming violent films, but this violence was pointless and needless and LOOOOONG.Thirdly, the cursed pirates turn into skeletons at midnight and are immortal (awesome) but they are just that and don't do anything special (big disappointment). When I say anything special, I'm comparing them to the warriors in The Mummy who actually had supernatural abilities. These pirates just change into skeletons and attack like you and me. Needless to say, it gets really boring after a while.Forthly, Deep's portrayal of the Jack Sparrow character was odd. In a majority of the scenes, he seemed like he was on some sort of narcotics. The last and final film gripe against this film was the accents the characters used. It was sometimes hard to understand some lines due to the mumbling.Anyway, the worst part of the film occured when it was over. As everyone stood up to exit, the movie received a full blown round of applause and cheers by little noisy children and their parents. Maybe I've seen too many films, but I was disappointed at this flick...</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-07-11</date>
		<username>connor_in_la</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Delivers what it promises and more</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl delivers on all the fun, adventure, and witty banter that people want when they go to a pirate movie - but which has been absent from movie theaters for years. This is no Cut-Throat Island (thank God) but rather more of an Errol Flynn-style swashbuckler (sorry, I had to use the word). Johnny Depp's character drives the story, swaying the actions of all those around him through clever - sometimes coy - manipulation of pretty much everyone. The fact that he's a bit off kilter and unexpectedly smart means that he's always half a step ahead of the audience. This makes for a rewarding, sometimes surprising story that keeps us engrossed. While this isn't rocket science, there's no dumbing-down here.Thoroughly recommended.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>This is one of those rare movies that captures your attention and keeps it all the way through. The magic of this film is something that makes the rest of the movies (Harry Potter included) seems mild in comparison!Johnny Depp, while not delivering his best performance, was consistently loveable and hate-able. He never fell out of character and he is one I loved to hate.The Pirate ship was truly a masterpiece. The shocks of ghosts surround and hold you close while making you squirm through ghosts and flesh. The pirates are absolutely terrifying when seen for what they are.While I do not recommend this for the squeamish or the faint of heart. It is a family film -- but only if your kids are teenagers! Don't be fooled into believing that you should take the little ones to this -- it is not a child's movie.Enjoy!</fullReview>

		<date>2003-07-10</date>
		<username>jedibuffy</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Excellent!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Saw this film twice yesterday... since I work at a theatre (an outdoor one to boot) I'll be seeing it just about as many times as is humanly possible over the next couple of weeks. Yes, I was one of the first to jump on the bandwagon about this movie when there were first even talks about making the ride a film - I love the Pirates ride, it's my favorite Disney ride and all that. When I heard who was going to be in it, I couldn't be more thrilled - I don't think I've ever seen a movie with Johnny Depp in it that I didn't like and Orlando Bloom stole my heart as he portrayed my favorite Lord of the Rings charactor - Legolas. Then the first trailers, even the teaser gave me goosebumps. I began to fear, however, that it could not possibly be as good as I was hopping it to be. I am happy to say that I was delightfully wrong.The story was cleaver, the acting surperb, the effects amazing and I had no idea how funny it was going to be - just the inside jokes (harkening back to the ride) alone were enough to have me rolling in the isles! At no time did this film take itself too serriously (something I am sure reviewers are going to do, a shame really).In a summer full of disapointments (i.e. The Hulk, The Matrix), I am excited and releaved that this is finally out and as good as it boasted. I'm sure many will disagree with me and I pity the people not able to let themselves have fun at the movies anymore.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-10</date>
		<username>maxcat741</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A Pirate's Life For Johnny</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Going in to 'Pirates', I have to admit that despite my outward enthusiasm, inwardly I was expecting a fluffy, cotton candy Disneyland movie. I almost hesitated on seeing the flick, in fears that I would never enjoy my favorite Disneyland ride again. However, adventure I did to the theatre, and exceedingly glad I am that I did so. Aye, the movie was fast-paced, but not 'Moulin Rouge'-so. It was adventurous, surprisingly well written, and the computer graphics were done very well. The filming was consistently done well, from the acrobatic fighting sequence between Capt. Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) and Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) to the magnificent shots of the dueling 'Interloper' and 'Black Pearl'.However, even with a great script, excellent plot and wonderful sets to boot, the captain of this fantastic voyage was wholeheartedly Johnny Depp. Playing the cocky, charming scoundrel Capt. Jack Sparrow, Depp unleashes a side of his acting persona that not many moviegoers have ever witnessed: comedy. Depp's varying facial expressions and swaying, seemingly-inebriated posture give him a swashbuckling charisma that captures your attention as he staggers through the picture, even in the company of Hollywood's latest teen-screen idol Orlando Bloom. Depp's genuinely funny with great comedic timing, yet he is also blessed with having genuinely hilarious punch lines to deliver. Reeling around in his three-corner hat, long, beaded black hair, and colorful pirate duds, Depp is a living, breathing replica of Disney's mechanical menaces. In the movie, he is the savior. Although Orlando Bloom, Geoffrey Rush, and especially new arrival Kiera Knightley do excellent in their respective roles, Depp not only steals every scene he is in, he walks away with the entire movie in his pocket. Whenever the plot drags (and it does, at seemingly the most random of occasions), Depp swings into the picture and delivers the action with a gleeful, devilish grin. He's the lovable rogue Hollywood has been missing for years.'Pirates' opens with young Elizabeth Swann meeting a shipwrecked boy named Will Turner with a mysterious pirate medallion strung around his neck. Years later, Elizabeth (played with a lot of spunk and gusto by Kiera Knightley) has grown up and is secretly in love with Will, now a blacksmith, while her father the governor wishes her to marry a British naval officer. Although a fainting spell lands Elizabeth into the deep trouble, the currently marooned Captain Jack Sparrow, pirate extraordinaire, rescues her from a watery grave. Despite his good intentions, Jack is welcomed with cordial hostility by the British navy, and winds up (by way of Will Turner) in the cooler (Look for a familiar scene around here, accompanied by a classic line by Jack: "You keep waving that bone around, he's never going to come").That night, pirates overrun the port and take Elizabeth hostage. Soon enough, she realizes that she's not in the company of ordinary buccaneers, but in a crew of the living dead, hexed for taking Cortes' cursed gold. The crew's appearance is drastically changed in moonlight, but worse than that, they cannot take pleasure in food, women, or (shiver me timbers!) even rum. To break the curse, they need to return all the coins and offer the blood sacrifice of one person...the child of a former mate in the crew. Turns out, Will's 'medallion' is really one of Cortes' gold pieces. Turns out, it's also in Elizabeth's possession. Now Will must team up with Jack to get back his girlfriend; at the same time, Jack tosses in with Will to get the 'Black Pearl'. The adventure is on.I hate the phrase, "If you see one movie this summer...' but I cannot help using it in this review. Do yourself a favor and see 'Pirates of the Caribbean', it doesn't matter if you're ten, seventeen, twenty-five, thirty-five, fifty, or ninety-nine...unless you have a heart condition. No, it's doubtful you'll be scared stiff by this flick, but you might bust an artery as fifty teen girls scream every time Orlando Bloom pokes his head onto the screen. Or whenever Johnny Depp wobbles across the screen with cunning one-liners. From his gleeful smirks, it's assumable that Depp had a ball making this movie. If you dare to see it, I promise you'll leave singing, `Yo-ho, yo-ho, a pirate's life for me.'</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-10</date>

		<fullReview>Disney never ceases to amaze me. 'Pirates' is a humorous yet well-portrayed movie. Johnny Depp as Jack Sparrow and Orlando Bloom as Will Turner are a kickass team in this movie of truth, honor, love, and adventure for the entire family! 8.8 out of 10.</fullReview>
